This method has only been proven to be effective for the exfoliation of a specific type of layered compounds, making it hard to be further extended for exfoliation of other layered materials, such as graphite, h-BN, TMDs, TMOs, MOFs, and COFs. For the anion exchange-assisted exfoliation method, most of the LDH nanosheets were exfoliated and dispersed in organic solvents with formamide being the most effective solvent.23,24 These organic solvents are toxic, and formamide has a high boiling point, which makes it hard to remove from the exfoliated nanosheets or to process further in other applications.

sections.heading: 4.5. Oxidation-Assisted Liquid Exfoliation
sections.text:
For the exfoliation of graphite, there is another widely used method, which is the oxidation-assisted liquid exfoliation method, also known as the modified Hummers’ method.72,73 The basic idea underlying this method is to use strong oxidizing agents to oxidize graphite to form graphite oxide. The oxidation of graphite can generate abundant oxygen-containing functional groups on the surface of each graphene layer, which can remarkably expand the interlayer spacing of bulk graphite crystals and thus significantly weaken the van der Waals interaction between adjacent layers.72,73 With subsequent sonication treatment, the expanded graphite oxide can be exfoliated into single-layer graphene oxide (GO) nanosheets.72−74 The most widely used oxidizing agent is a mixture of potassium permanganate and concentrated sulfuric acid.74 This method allows for the preparation of single-layer GO nanosheets in high yield and large amount in the solution phase. One of the major disadvantages is the usage of strong oxidizing agents in this process, making this method not very safe as compared to other methods, for example, the sonicationassisted liquid exfoliation method. Although it is very effective for the preparation of GO nanosheets, it is hard to further extend this method to other layered materials.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6240
Of particular interest is that abundant oxygen-containing functional groups, such as carboxyl, epoxy, and hydroxyl groups, will be generated on the GO surface due to the oxidation.410 These oxygen-containing groups on GO nanosheets can be partially removed after reduction to produce reduced GO (rGO) nanosheets. The reduction of GO nanosheets can be achieved by many strategies, such as chemical reduction via reducing agents, thermal annealing, photochemical reduction, electrochemical reduction, and so on.411−417 Residual functional groups on the surface of rGO nanosheets may still exist even after the reduction.310 Both GO and rGO nanosheets have different physical, chemical, and electronic properties as compared to the pristine graphene or CVD-grown graphene. One of the obvious differences is that graphene has an excellent electrical conductivity,418−420 while GO nanosheet is electrically insulating.418−420 Even after reduction back to its rGO form, the electrical conductivity of rGO sheets is still not as good as those obtained from mechanical exfoliation or CVD-grown. Moreover, GO nanosheet is amphiphilic and can be well dispersed in water,421,422 while graphene is highly hydrophobic.423 Because of their distinctive properties from graphene, GO and rGO were defined as graphene derivatives rather than graphene, although graphene has been widely used to name rGO nanosheets in many published papers. In this case, GO and rGO nanosheets can be regarded as a unique class of carbonaceous ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, with interesting properties unattainable from other ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. The abundant functional groups on GO nanosheets allow them to be easily modified with organic or polymeric molecules via covalent bonds.424 The electrical conductivity of GO nanosheets can be easily tuned from insulating to highly conductive by precisely controlling the amount of oxygen-containing functional groups on its surface.410 The rich functional groups on the GO surface can be used as nucleation sites to facilitate the growth of other nanocrystals (noble metals, metal oxides, metal chalcogenides, or MOFs) on their surface, making them ideal dispersible templates for the construction of functional composites in the solution phase.425−437

sections.heading: 4.6. Selective Etching-Assisted Liquid Exfoliation
sections.text:
The selective etching-assisted liquid exfoliation method was developed by Gogotsi’s group for the preparation of ultrathin 2D nanosheets of early transition metal carbides and/or carbonitrides, that is, MXenes, by using bulk MAX phases as the starting materials.25,77 MAX phases have a general formula of Mn+1AXn (n = 1, 2, or 3), in which M, A, and X represent early transition metal, element of group IIIA or IVA, and C and/or N, respectively.438 In bulk crystals of Mn+1AXn, the M layers are nearly close-packed with filled X atoms at the octahedral sites, and the layers of A atoms are sandwiched between the Mn+1Xn layers. The in-plane M−X bond is a mixed covalent/metallic/ionic, while the out-of-plane M−A bond is metallic. Considering its crystal structure, Mn+1AXn phases can be also regarded as a kind of layered materials, in which the 2D Mn+1Xn layers are connected by the A layers.
25 Different from those traditional van der Waals layered materials, the metallic bonding between Mn+1Xn layers in Mn+1AXn phases is much stronger than the van der Waals interaction in conventional layered compounds such as graphite and TMDs. Therefore, aforementioned exfoliation methods are ineffective for exfoliation of MAX phases. Bearing this in mind, Gogotsi and co-workers developed an elective etching-assisted liquid
exfoliation method for preparing MXenes from bulk Mn+1AXn phases.25,77 The basic idea is to use a strong etching agent (e.g., HF) to etch away the A layers without breaking the bonds in Mn+1Xn layers using selective experimental conditions (Figure 14).25,78 As a result, after the etching of A layers, the remaining
etched crystals consist of loosely packed Mn+1Xn layers, which can be easily exfoliated into single- or few-layer nanosheets via a subsequent sonication treatment (Figure 14).25,78 The obtained nanosheets have a general formula of Mn+1Xn, named as MXenes by Gogotsi and co-workers.25 It is worth pointing out that the chemical composition of the obtained nanosheets by this method is different from that of the originally used bulk crystals, which is also different from other exfoliation methods. In 2011, Gogotsi and co-workers first reported this method for the production of the Ti3C2 nanosheet from the Ti3AlC2 bulk crystal.77 In a typical process, the powder of Ti3AlC2 bulk crystal was dispersed in a 50% concentrated HF solution at room temperature for a given time (e.g., 2 h) to etch away the Al layers. After being washed several times with water, the etched intermediate product was sonicated in water to obtained a dispersed Ti3C2 nanosheet.
77 Notably, the experimental conditions, such as the concentration of HF aqueous solution, the reaction time, and temperature, need to be tuned to find the optimized conditions. MXenes prepared by this method normally possess some functional groups (e.g., OH, F, O, H, etc.) on their surface, which are favorable for stabilizing them in solution and some specific applications. This method is a simple and general method for the high yield and massive production of MXenes from MAX phases in solution. Note that this method needs to use strong corrosive chemical, that is, HF, as etchant, which makes the preparation process relatively dangerous. Gogotsi and co-workers reported that the mixture of fluoride salts (e.g., LiF, NaF, KF, and CsF) and HCl or H2SO4 can be used to replace the strong corrosive HF as the etchant for the MAX phases to prepare MXenes.199 This finding provided a much safer way to produce MXenes by using the selective etching-assisted liquid exfoliation, greatly promoting its potential for practical applications. To date, this method has been successfully applied to prepare many other MXenes, such as Ti2C, Nb2C, Ti4N3, V2C, (Ti0.5,Nb0.5)2C, (V0.5,Cr0.5)3C2, Ti3CN, Ta4C3, Mo2TiC2, Mo2Ti2C3, Cr2TiC2, Mo2CTx, and Al3C3.
25,77−80,199,439−447 Because there are more than 60 different compounds in MAX phases, it is believed that more
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6241
MXenes can be prepared by using this method in the near future. There are several limitations to this method. This method cannot be used to prepare all MXenes from the MAX phases.25 It is hard to further extend this method for the preparation of other ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene, TMDs, and metal oxides.

sections.heading: 4.7. Chemical Vapor Deposition
sections.text:
CVD is a traditional technique for the preparation of highpurity materials or thin films such as W, Ti, Ta, Zr, and Si on substrates.81 The first utilization of CVD technique in industry dates back to 1897, when de Lodyguine first used it to reduce tungsten hexachloride with hydrogen to coat tungsten on carbon filament for lamps.448 Currently, the CVD method has been used for the massive production of highly purified polycrystalline silicon in industry. The key step for the production of single crystal silicon, CVD is widely used for many modern technologies, such as electronics and solar cell devices.449 Over the past decade, CVD method has also been continuously developed and recognized as a reliable and powerful technique for producing a large number of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.81 In a typical process, the preselected substrates are put in a furnace chamber, and one or more gas/ vapor precursors are cycled through the chamber, in which the precursors can react and/or decompose on the surface of substrates.81 In this case, ultrathin 2D nanosheets can be obtained on the substrate in proper experimental conditions. In some growth processes, catalysts need to be used in the reaction process, for example, for growing graphene.82 In 2006, Somani and co-workers first demonstrated the growth of thick graphene from camphor pyrolysis on a Ni substrate by the CVD technique.450 Although the graphene resulted from this work is about 30 layers, it proved the possibility for the growth of single- or few-layer graphene by the CVD technique.450 Inspired by this work, many efforts have been devoted to optimizing experimental conditions to achieve the growth of single- or few-layer graphene sheets. Beton and co-workers achieved the growth of single-layer graphene by CVD method on polycrystalline Ni film deposited on the SiO2/Si substrate.451 Note that the Ni film here not only acted as the substrate to support the growth of graphene, but also as the catalyst to facilitate the nucleation of precursors to form graphene sheets. Significantly, Ruoff and co-workers demonstrated the growth of large-area single-layer graphene film up to 0.5 mm on copper foil by the CVD method by using methane and hydrogen as gas sources.84 It is worth pointing out that the precursors, substrates, catalysts, temperature, and atmospheres are among the key factors in determining the structure features of the final graphene products in the CVD growth.82 By finetuning those experimental parameters, the controlled growth of graphene with tunable layer number, crystallinity, and lateral size can be achieved on different substrates with different precursors by the CVD technique.81,82 Likewise, CVD can be extended for the growth of many other 2D nanosheets on various substrates, such as h-BN nanosheets,452−456 topological insulators (e.g., In2Se3 and Bi2Se3), 457−465 metal carbides,466,467 silicene,42,468 borophenes,469−471 and antimonene.472
Not only limited to the aforementioned nanosheets, singleor few-layer TMDs have also been grown by the CVD technique on various substrates.87,473 Although the growth of TMDs dated back to the 1980s,474 the growth of ultrathin 2D TMD nanosheets was only achieved a few years ago. In 2012, Li and co-workers first demonstrated the growth of few-layer
MoS2 nanosheets on insulating substrates by the thermal decomposition of ammonium thiomolybdates that was dipcoated onto the substrates with a subsequent sulfurization using sulfur vapor (Figure 15).475 Alternatively, the CVD growth of
large-area few-layer MoS2 nanosheets was achieved by sulfurization of Mo metal film by sulfur vapor, in which the Mo film was predeposited on the SiO2 substrate using an electronic beam evaporator.476 The size and thickness of the film can roughly be tuned by controlling the size of the substrate and the thickness of Mo metal film. TMOs and transition metal chlorides (e.g., MoO3 and MoCl5) can also be used as the Mo sources to produce MoS2 nanosheets by the CVD technique.477−481 Up to now, many ultrathin 2D nanosheets of TMDs, including MoS2, 474−481 WS2, 482−485 MoSe2, 486−488 WSe2, 489−492 ZrS2, 493,494 ReS2, 495,496 MoTe2, 497−499 etc., have been grown by the CVD technique from different precursors at different temperatures on various substrates under different atmosphere. CVD technique has the highest level of control among all other synthetic methods for ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. Recent studies have proven that not only pure TMD nanosheets, but also alloyed TMD nanosheets (e.g., MoS2xSe2(1−x), MoxW1−xS2, and WS2xSe2(1−x)) have also been prepared by controlling the experimental conditions in the CVD technique.500−511 The bandgap of alloyed TMD nanosheets can be finely tuned by adjusting the ratio of elemental compositions. It has been demonstrated significantly that 2D TMD heteronanostructures (e.g., WSe2−WS2, MoSe2−MoS2, and MoSe2−WSe2) can also be prepared by epitaxial growth of another TMDs on an existing TMD seed.512−521 By tuning the experimental conditions, the epitaxial mode, that is, lateral and vertical growth, can also be controlled in the growth of 2D TMD heteronanostructures to obtain lateral and vertical specifications.512 Because of different band gaps of different TMD nanosheets, ultrathin 2D lateral and vertical TMD heteronanostructures can be regarded as the natural p−n junctions with atomic thickness, which are ideal candidates for the construction of high-performance electronic devices in modern electronics/optoelectronics.522,523
The CVD technique allows researchers to prepare ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with high crystal quality, high purity, and limited defects on certain substrates with scalable size and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6242
controllable thickness. Significantly, the electronic properties of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene and TMDs, are approaching those of mechanically exfoliated thin layers. Therefore, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials grown by the CVD technique are also promising candidates for the fabrication of high-performance electronic and optoelectronics devices. Unlike the low yield and low production rate of the micromechanical cleavage technique, CVD is capable of producing materials in industry scale, a proven case for materials such as polycrystalline silicon. It is believed that CVD technique is a promising method with potential to produce ultrathin 2D nanomaterials in industry applications for electronics and optoelectronics. The CVD method still has some disadvantages at its current form. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials grown by the CVD technique are always deposited on the substrates, needing to be transferred to other substrates for further investigation and applications. The CVD technique normally needs high temperature and inert atmosphere, leading to relatively high cost of production as compared to the solution-based methods.

sections.heading: 4.8. Wet-Chemical Syntheses
sections.text:
Wet-chemical syntheses, which belong to the bottom-up approaches, are also good choices for the preparation of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials in high yield and large amount.89,90 Wet-chemical syntheses represent all of the synthetic methods that rely on the chemical reactions of certain precursors at proper experimental conditions conducted in solution phase.524 Because of their powerful controllability, wet-chemical syntheses have been considered as a class of convenient and reproducible strategies for the preparation of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with controlled size and thickness, which are potentially scalable for industrial applications. Particularly, wetchemical syntheses have been widely used for preparing various nonlayer structured ultrathin 2D nanomaterials because they are unable to be prepared by those top-down methods.90 The synthesized 2D nanomaterials can easily be dispersed in organic or aqueous media, which make them very suitable for various applications. Wet-chemical syntheses can be also used for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with layered structural features.89 Unlike all of the methods discussed above, there are no general principles underlying each wet-chemical synthesis method. One wet-chemical synthesis method could be as different from the other. To classify, hydro/solvothermal synthesis, 2D-oriented attachment, 2D-templated synthesis, self-assembly of nanocrystals, hot-injection method, interfacemediated synthesis, and on-surface synthesis are a few routines. In this section, we focus on the introduction of these typical wet-chemical protocols for the preparation of 2D ultrathin nanosheets and provide some representative examples for each protocol. The advances and limitations of each synthetic route are also discussed. 4.8.1. Hydro/Solvothermal Synthesis. The hydro/ solvothermal synthesis method is a typical wet-chemical synthesis strategy, using water or organic solvent as the reaction medium in a sealed vessel, in which the used reaction temperature is higher than the boiling point of the solvent.525 When the reaction temperature of the closed system is heated above the boiling point of the solvent system, the solvent will be autogenerated in high pressure to promote the reaction and improve the crystallinity of the as-synthesized nanocrystals. This method has been widely used to prepare ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, especially inorganic materials.90 As a typical
example, Xie and co-workers used the solvothermal method to prepare freestanding 4-atom-thick Co nanosheets with and without surface cobaltoxide by using dimethylformamide as the reductant.526 As another interesting example, Li and co-workers prepared single-layer Rh nanosheets with an edge length of 500−600 nm through a facile solvothermal synthetic approach by using PVP as the surfactant.29 Remarkably, this report is the first example for the realization of the synthesis of single-layer metal nanosheets. In addition to metal nanosheets, a lot of ultrathin 2D nanosheets of metal oxides and metal chalcogenides have also been synthesized by this method.209,527−531 For instance, Dou and co-workers demonstrated a general solvothermal method for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D transition metal oxide nanosheets, including TiO2, ZnO, Co3O4, WO3, Fe3O4, and MnO2, by using the poly(ethylene oxide)-poly(propylene oxide)-poly(ethylene oxide) (P123) and ethylene glycol as surfactants in ethanol.527 Using this strategy, TMOs of TiO2 (∼200 nm), ZnO (1−10 μm), Co3O4 (1−10 μm), WO3 (1−10 μm), Fe3O4, and MnO2 nanosheets with thickness ranging from 1.6 to 5.2 nm (corresponding to 2−7 stacking monolayers) have been prepared. Driven by the hydrophobic effect of the oleate tails, Xie and co-workers prepared ultrathin CeCO3OH nanosheets.
209 The CeCO3OH nanosheet could be transformed into the CeO2 nanosheet with 3-atom-layer thickness via the thermal treatment at 400 °C for 2 min in air. As a typical member of TMDs, the MoS2 nanosheet can also be synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method.205,532−534 Xie and co-workers reported the preparation of few-layer defect-rich MoS2 nanosheet with the assistance of excess thiourea.205 The same group also prepared the oxygenincorporated MoS2 nanosheet in water at 200 °C using a similar hydrothermal method, which showed an enlarged interlayer spacing of 9.5 Å as compared to the pristine 2H-MoS2 at 6.15 Å.532 Later, Wei and co-workers prepared 2H-MoS2 nanosheet by using a similar synthetic procedure.533 The 2H-MoS2 nanosheet can be partially transformed into metallic 1T phase by a second solvothermal treatment.533 Because of the presence of metallic 1T phase, the MoS2 nanosheet with mixed 2H and 1T phases showed robust ferromagnetism at room temperature. The hydro/solvothermal synthesis method is a simple and scalable method for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials in high yield and low cost. However, it is hard to figure out the growth mechanism for the hydro/solvothermal synthesis process because all of the reactions occur in a sealed autoclave, thus making it difficult to design experiments for other material systems. The hydro/solvothermal synthesis is quite sensitive to the experimental conditions, such as the concentration of precursors, solvent systems, used surfactants or polymers, and temperature, making it difficult to precisely control the structure in different batches and laboratories. Most of the 2D nanosheets synthesized by the hydro/solvothermal synthesis method were few-layer rather than single-layer.
4.8.2. 2D-Oriented Attachment. The 2D-oriented attachment is another typical wet-chemical synthesis method used for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.90 Unlike the classical mechanism, the 2D-oriented attachment shows a peculiar growth process and achieves nanostructures with welldefined morphology.535,536 In the 2D-oriented attachment, adjacent nanocrystals are connected with each other and fused together to form single-crystalline 2D nanosheets by sharing a common crystallographic facet to eliminate the high energy facets and interfaces.537−539 In 2010, Weller and co-workers developed this method for the synthesis of PbS nanosheets
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6243
from tiny PbS nanocrystals.540 It was found that PbS nanocrystals were attached in a 2D orientation to form single-crystalline nanosheets with size of 0.8−2 μm and thickness of about 2.2 nm (Figure 16).537,540 The dense
packing of oleic acid ligands on {100} surface of PbS nanocrystals is the key point for this growth process. The presence of chlorine-containing compounds also assists in triggering the oriented attachment process by exposing the highly reactive {110} facets (Figure 16). On the basis of this work, Sun and co-workers prepared PbS nanosheets with different thicknesses by tuning the reaction temperature and the corresponding chlorine-containing compounds.541 Vanmaekelbergh and co-workers reported a two-steps method (assembly and oriented attachment) for the synthesis of 2D PbSe nanosheets with a honeycomb superlattice.542 In their experiments, PbSe nanocrystals terminated with {100}, {110}, and {111} facets were first prepared. They found that the PbSe nanocrystals attached together via the {100} facets to form a 2D honeycomb superlattice with octahedral symmetry. The 2D PbSe honeycomb structure could be transformed into a 2D CdSe superlattice through a cation exchange reaction. Nowadays, 2D-oriented attachment is considered as the exclusive way to prepare 2D nanocrystals with nonlayered structures. Various 2D nanosheets with layered structures can also be prepared by the 2D-oriented attachment method. Jeong and co-workers synthesized Bi2Se3 nanosheet by a simple and quick solution process.543 The growth mechanism involved in oriented attachment of small nanocrystals followed by epitaxial recrystallization into nanosheets. The driving force for this kind of 2D oriented attachment was the intrinsic tendency of a layered structure with negatively charged Se atoms. In their experiment, they found that the amine-containing surfactants preferred to enlarge the lateral dimension and get larger sized nanosheets. By using the oleylamine as solvent and surfactants, Wang and co-workers prepared a single-layer SnSe nanosheet with the lateral size of ∼300 nm and thickness of ∼1 nm by the coalescence of the SnSe nucleus in an oriented attachment mechanism.544
4.8.3. Self-Assembly of Nanocrystals. Impelled by the development of nanocrystal synthesis and surface modification technologies, self-assembly of nanocrystals has been developed as one of the efficient ways to create nanoarchitectures with inner nanocrystals in ordered and steady manner, in which presynthesized nanocrystals spontaneously organize with each other by noncovalent interactions, such as van der Waals interactions, electrostatic interactions, and/or hydrogen bonds.545 It has been demonstrated that the assembly of lowdimensional nanocrystals, such as nanoparticles and nanowires, is a promising strategy to prepare ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.90 The assembly process of nanocrystals mostly involves the fusion of low-dimensional nanocrystals to form larger crystals in two dimensions. Although the 2D-oriented attachment method discussed in section 4.8.2 also belongs to the assembly strategy, it is worthy to discuss it in a separate section because it has been well studied and widely used for a number of materials. In 2006, Kotov and co-workers first reported the preparation of polycrystalline 2D CdTe nanosheet with thickness of ∼3.4 nm by the self-assembly of CdTe nanocrystals (3.4 nm in diameter).546 It was suggested that the self-assembly process was driven by the dipole moment, small positive charge, and directional hydrophobic attraction. Wu and co-workers prepared ultrathin Cu nanosheet by self-assembly of dodecanethiol capped Cu nanoclusters.547,548 The assembled Cu nanosheet gives strong luminescent intensity, although the original Cu nanoclusters are nonluminescent.548 Later, the same group reported that the 2D Au nanosheet could be also obtained by self-assembly of dodecanethiol capped Au nanoclusters.549 The thickness of the assembled Au nanosheets could be tuned from 1.5 to 100 nm by adjusting the concentration of Au nanoclusters and reaction temperature. In another example, Cheng and co-workers prepared an artificial membrane based on bilayered Au nanosheets by selfassembly of polystyrene capped Au nanoparticles at the liquid/ air interface.550 Besides nanoparticles, nanowires have also been used as building blocks to prepare ultrathin 2D nanosheets via the assembly strategy. Acharya and co-workers prepared an ultrathin 2D PbS nanosheet via the coalescence of PbS nanowires.551 Initially, the supercrystalline-assembled PbS nanowires were obtained with the assistance of the capping ligand trioctylamine. The supercrystalline nanowires were then assembled into single-crystalline nanosheets with regularly rectangular shape at the air/water interface with the assistance of surface pressure and temperature. By using a similar strategy, Yao and co-workers synthesized Eu2O3 nanosheet by selfassembly of Eu2O3 nanowires.
552 In their experiment, the Eu2O3 nanowire bundles were first prepared by using 1,5- pentanediol as the capping and structure directing agents. After being soaked in water, the nanowire bundles gradually selfassembled into sheet-like porous structures, and finally transformed into ultrathin rectangle Eu2O3 nanosheet with thickness of ∼3.8 nm. The lateral size of Eu2O3 nanosheets could be tuned from several hundred nanometers to 10 μm by simply adjusting the soaking time of the bundles in water.
4.8.4. 2D-Templated Synthesis. Templated synthesis is an effective strategy for growth of anisotropic nanostructures, which refers to the use of the presynthesized nanomaterials or bulk substrates as templates to confine/direct the growth of specific nanostructures.553,554 Over the past few years, tremendous efforts have been made in 2D-templated synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanosheets.555−558 For instance, by using the GO nanosheet as template, Zhang and co-workers achieved the
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6244
growth of hexagonal close-packed (hcp) Au square nanosheet with size between 200 and 500 nm and thickness of ∼2.4 nm via wet-chemical synthesis method (Figure 17).284 Normally, the face-centered cubic ( fcc) structure is the most stable phase of the gold and can be easily obtained by wet-chemical methods. To highlight, this is the first time that pure hcp Au structure that is stable under ambient conditions has been prepared by a solution-based method. The hcp Au nanosheet can be transformed to the fcc phase via phase transformation induced by the e-beam irradiation in a TEM, a secondary growth step, surface ligand exchange, or coating of a metal thin layer.559,560 As another example, Wei and co-workers demonstrated the synthesis of a freestanding half-unit-cell αFe2O3 nanosheet by using CuO nanoplate as the template. 561 After the synthesis of layered iron hydroxide nanosheet on the surface of CuO nanoplate, freestanding iron hydroxide nanosheet can be obtained by slowly etching away the CuO template. After that, the iron hydroxide nanosheet was further transformed into freestanding α-Fe2O3 nanosheet by a simple thermal annealing treatment. The obtained α-Fe2O3 nanosheet has size of up to ∼1 μm and thickness of 0.55−0.59 nm. By using layered α-Ni(OH)2 nanosheet as the template, NiO nanosheet with size of up to micrometer and thickness <2 nm was synthesized by Li and co-workers via thermal annealing treatment.562 Prasad and co-workers found that the metal thiolates existed as lamellar assemblies in the neat state.563 The lamellar structure of Pd thiolates could be isolated into a single nanosheet by diluting it in toluene. Through heat treatment on the single nanosheet of Pd thiolates coated on an appropriate substrate, ultrathin Pd nanosheet could be prepared. A lot of 2D semiconductor nanosheets have also been prepared by the 2D-templated synthesis method. Zhang and co-workers prepared copper-based ternary and quaternary chalcogenide nanoplates including CuInS2, CuInxGa1−xS2, and Cu2ZnSnS4 via the cation exchange reaction using presynthesized CuS nanoplate as the template.564 The resultant ternary and quaternary nanoplates have size, shape, and thickness similar to those of its CuS nanoplate template. The cubic-phased Cu2−xSe nanosheet was prepared by simple heating treatment of the preprepared hexagonal-phased CuSe nanosheet in the presence of CuI.565 Using this template-assisted phase transformation method, hexagonal-phased CuS nanosheet could be also transformed into cubic-phased Cu1.97S nanosheet. Nanosheets with thickness of ∼1 nm were successfully prepared by a lamellar mesophase template process.566 The low-angle XRD characterization on the precursor mixture of Pb(OAc)2·3H2O and n-octylamine established the existence of the lamellar-template structure. 4.8.5. Hot-Injection Method. The hot-injection method, initially developed by Bawendi and co-workers for the synthesis
of cadmium chalcogenide nanocrystals, is a very attractive approach to prepare monodispersed colloidal nanocrystals with uniform size, shape, and high purity.567 The hot-injection method driven by high initial supersaturation involved the rapid injection of the highly reactive reactants into a hot solution containing long-chain oleyl amine and/or oleic acid surfactants. This method has been extended to synthesize ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, especially 2D metal chalcogenide nanostructures.568−575 As a typical example, a single-layer CdSe nanosheet was synthesized using this method by heating the reactants of CdCl2 and Se powder in a mixture solution of octylamine and oleylamine.576 Ultrathin 2D CdSe and CdTe nanosheets were also obtained by slight modification of the experimental conditions. Single-crystalline GeS and GeSe nanosheets with the average lateral dimensions of 2−4 μm × 0.5−1 μm and thickness of ∼5 nm were also synthesized by heating the mixture of GeI4, hexamethyldisilazane, oleylamine, oleic acid, and dodecanethiol or trioctylphosphine selenide to 320 °C for 24 h.577,578 In 2012, Zhang and co-workers used the hot-injection method to achieve the generalized synthesis of ultrathin metal sulfide nanocrystals.579 Particularly, CuS nanosheet with a regular hexagonal shape was synthesized in gram amount. The resultant CuS nanosheet is ∼3.2 nm (two unit cells) and ∼453 nm in thickness and lateral size, respectively. Yan and co-workers synthesized a series of 2D trivalent rare earth (RE)-selenium nanosheets, that is, RESe2 (RE = La, Nd) and RE4O4Se3 (RE = Nd, Sm, Gd, Ho), in which all of the nanosheets contain Se with −1 valence in planar Se layers.580 Note that all of the aforementioned metal chalcogenide nanosheets are nonlayer structured materials. 2D nanosheets of layered metal chalcogenides, for example, TMDs, can be synthesized by this method. As a typical example, Cheon and co-workers reported the synthesis of single-layer MoSe2 and WSe2 nanosheets with lateral size of 200−400 nm by using the hot-injection method.581 In their experiments, they found that the capping ligands were very important for controlling the number of layer in nanosheets. By changing the capping ligands from oleic acid to oleyl alcohol and oleylamine, the thickness of the nanosheets could be tuned from single layer to 2−3 layers and 4−8 layers. The same group also prepared a series of groups IV and V transition metal sulfide and selenide nanosheets, such as TiS2, ZrS2, HfS2, VS2, NbS2, TaS2, TiSe2, ZrSe3, HfSe3, VSe2, NbSe2, and TaSe2, by using the CS2 and Se powder as the injection chalcogen precursors.582−585 As an interesting example, Ozin and co-workers demonstrated the synthesis of 2D WS2 nanosheets with controllable crystal phase by simply tuning the injecting precursors. By injecting the CS2 and WCl6 precursors into hot oleylamine solution (320 °C), single-layer metallic WS2 nanosheet with a distorted octahedral (1T′) phase was obtained, and the as-prepared nanosheet has a
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6245
round-shaped morphology with the diameter of ∼100 nm (Figure 18).586 In contrast, by introducing a small amount of
hexamethyldisilazane in the reaction system, a flower-like WS2 nanosheet with a normal hexagonal (2H) phase was obtained (Figure 18).586 In addition to binary nanosheets, ternary layered nanostructures can also be obtained using this method. Gupta and co-workers prepared CuSbS2 nanosheet with tunable thickness from single- to few-layers.587 The hotinjection method allows for the synthesis of colloidal 2D metal chalcogenide nanosheets with good dispersity, high purity, uniform size, and shape. However, some disadvantages still remain on this method. First, long-chain oleyl amine and/or oleic acid surfactants are normally used in the hot-injection process, which are not easy to remove and unfavorable for applications, such as electronics, catalysis, and energy storage. Second, the reaction temperature for the hot-inject method normally is relatively high (e.g., 300−350 °C) due to the use of high boiling point solvent in the system. Third, because of the limits of the precursor injection, this method usually cannot be used for large-scale production. In contrast, large-scale production might be achieved in the one-pot heating method, in which all of the reactants are mixed into the high boiling point solvent (such as oleylamine, oleic acid, octadecene) at room temperature with subsequent heating of the mixture to the higher temperature to get the target products.588−596
4.8.6. Interface-Mediated Synthesis. The interfacemediated synthesis method is another typical wet-chemical synthesis method used for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, especially for metal coordination polymers (CPs) and polymers.597,598 In 2011, Schlüter and co-workers first achieved the synthesis of single-layer CP nanosheet at the water/air interface.599 The basic idea is to confine the ligand at the water/air interface before reacting it with metal salt
dissolved in water to form CP nanosheets. In a typical process, hexafunctionalterpyridine (tpy)-based organic ligand was dissolved in chloroform, and the solution was added dropwise on the top of metal salt aqueous solution.599 The organic ligand was confined in two dimensions at the water/air interface due to the fast evaporation of the chloroform and low solubility of the ligand in water. Therefore, the ligand at the interface reacted with metal ion dissolved in water to form single-layer dense CP nanosheets, that is, [M2+2(tpy)
4+]x (0 < x < 3; M = Fe, Ru, Zn), at the water/air interface, which can be easily transferred onto any other substrates. The crystal structure of the 2D CP nanosheets needs to be further characterized. Later, the same group further extended this method for the synthesis of a series of 2D CP nanosheets based on the reaction between an oligo-functionalized terpyridine-based ligand and different transition metal salts (Fe2+, Co2+/3+, Zn2+, and Pb2+) at the water/air interface.600 They also demonstrated that the asprepared 2D CP nanosheets could be promising building blocks to fabricate multilayer assemblies on solid substrates by using the layer-by-layer deposition method. As an interesting example, Nishihara and co-workers reported the synthesis of a single-layer nickel bis(dithiolene) nanosheet at the water/air interface by using the interface-mediated method.601 In their case, the single-layer CP nanosheet was obtained under atmospheric pressure rather than compressed pressure used for the Langmuir−Blodgett method. Feng and co-workers also used the interface-mediated synthesis method to prepare a single-layer CP nanosheet of nickel bis(dithiolene) complex.602 The 1,2,5,6,9,10-triphenylenehexathiol (THT) molecule was used as the ligand in this study. Nishihara and co-workers achieved the synthesis of 2D CP nanosheet of bis(dipyrrinato)zinc(II) laminar complex at the water/air interface (Figure 19),603 in which the complex three-way dipyrrin ligand directly reacted with the zinc acetate at atmospheric pressure to form the nanosheet. In addition to CPs, 2D COF nanosheets have also been prepared by the interface-mediated synthesis method. On the basis of their rich experience on the interface-mediated synthesis of 2D CP nanosheets, Schlüter and co-workers first demonstrated the synthesis of COF nanosheets at the water/air interface.604 An amphiphilic monomer, able to preorganize on the water surface through intermolecular interactions, was designed and synthesized. Such smart design of the molecular structure from the monomer ensures the anthracene units to stack face-to-face. In this case, monomers were bonded together via a [4+4]-cycloaddition reaction upon UV light irradiation to form the single-layer COF nanosheet. Later, King and co-workers used an analogous method to prepare another single-layer COF nanosheet at the water/air interface via UV
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6246
light irradiation, in which the monomer consists of a diethylene glycol chain and three anthraceno blades functionalized with a trypticene core.605 The lateral size of the obtained COF nanosheet can be up to 1 mm2. Not limited to water/air interface, Bao and co-workers reported the synthesis of an imine-based COF nanosheet at the DMF/air interface.606 Unlike the synthesis on water/air interface, DMF solution containing residual monomers after the synthesis of the COF powder was used as the reaction solution, which was left undisturbed in a water saturated atmosphere. As a consequence, a thin COF nanosheet was obtained at the DMF/air interface after a certain time. The thickness of the COF nanosheet can be easily tuned from 1.8 to 29 nm by controlling the incubation time. Besides CPs and polymers, 2D inorganic nanosheets could be also prepared by the interface-mediated synthesis method. Wang and co-workers reported the preparation of freestanding ZnO nanosheet at the water/air interface.607 In a typical process, Zn(NO3)2 and hexamethylenetetramine were first dissolved in a glass vial filled with water, and a solution of sodium oleyl sulfate dissolved in chloroform was dropped on the surface of the aqueous solution. The solution was then heated to 60 °C for about 1 h 40 min to evaporate chloroform and obtain the ZnO nanosheet at the air/water interface. The obtained ZnO nanosheet is single-crystalline, has thickness of 1−2 nm, and has lateral size up to tens of micrometers. This method might be further extended to prepare other ultrathin 2D metal oxide nanosheets at the water/air interface. 4.8.7. On-Surface Synthesis. The on-surface synthesis method has been developed as a promising way for the synthesis of ultrathin 2D COF nanosheets from monomers on solid substrates.608−611 In a typical process, the monomers for a certain COF were casted on the surface of a solid substrate, which then reacted into COF nanosheets through the polymerization process due to the surface confinement of the solid substrate. As a typical example, Lei and co-workers first developed this method for the single-layer imine-based COF on the highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) surface.608 In their experiment, a mixed solution of benzene-1,3,5-tricarbaldehyde and aromatic diamide was drop-casted on the HOPG substrate, and then the substrate was heated to facilitate the diffusion of monomers and oligomers for obtaining large surface coverage and to complete the monomer reaction in forming single-layer COF. Later, the same group further demonstrated the preparation of the same single-layer COF on single-layer graphene supported on a copper foil.609 Inspired by their work, Wang and co-workers demonstrated the preparation of COF nanosheets with one nonaromatic monomer, such as hydrazine and glyoxal, using the on-surface synthesis method.610 The resultant COF nanosheets showed more defects as compared to the aforementioned COFs due to the higher flexibility of the monomers. Wan and co-workers achieved the synthesis of nearly defect-free single-layer COF nanosheet on the HOPG substrate by slight modification of the experimental conditions of the on-surface synthesis method.611 In their case, one monomer was first drop-casted on the HOPG substrate. The HOPG substrate loaded with this monomer was sealed into a vessel containing another volatile monomer. Upon heating the vessel at a proper temperature, the volatile monomer will vaporize and slowly react with the monomer deposited on the HOPG substrate surface to form the COF nanosheet, in which a hydrated salt was added in the reaction medium to adjust the humidity in the system. The major
disadvantage of this method is that one of the monomers needs to be more volatile than the other to ensure that the main monomer will not decompose before the volatile monomer vaporizes.
4.8.8. Other Wet-Chemical Synthesis Methods. Other wet-chemical synthesis methods have also been developed to synthesize specific ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, which cannot be categorized into the other methods. Zheng and co-workers reported the synthesis of freestanding hexagonal Pd nanosheet by a CO-confined growth method in solution.28 The strong adsorption of CO on the basal (111) planes of Pd nanosheets was believed to be the key factor for the confined growth of Pd nanocrystals in two dimensions to form nanosheets. The synthesized Pd nanosheets have thickness of ∼1.8 nm and tunable edge lengths between 20 and 160 nm (Figure 20a,b).28
In another example, Xie and co-workers reported a simple and green approach for the synthesis of single-layer β-Co(OH)2 nanosheet based on the reaction between cobalt chloride and aminoethanol aqueous solution under ambient atmospheric conditions.153 Yan and co-workers reported the preparation of several rare-earth oxide nanosheets by a one-pot colloidal synthesis method.612 The synthesized 2D nanosheets of Gd2O3, Ho2O3, and Y2O3 have lateral sizes large than 100 nm and thicknesses less than 1 nm. Two different groups independently reported the preparation of layered synthetic 2D polymer single crystals by the single-crystal-to-single-crystal photopolymerization process and the subsequent exfoliation of them into 2D polymer nanosheets.34,35 For the synthesis of the fluorinated hydrocarbon 2D polymer nanosheet, King and co-workers first prepared the triptycene-based single-crystalline monomer that is composed of three photoreactive tetrafluoroanthraceno “blades” connected to each other by a [2.2.2] bicyclic core.34 The photopolymerization of the single-crystalline monomer by
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6247
[4+4] cycloaddition was achieved by first irradiating the monomer single crystal with 460 nm light followed by irradiation with 400 nm light. In this case, polymer bulk crystal with a layered structure that is similar to that of graphite was obtained after the photopolymerization process. The obtained polymer bulk crystal was then exfoliated into single- or fewlayer nanosheet by rotating them in NMP at 50 °C for several days. Concurrently, Schlüter and co-workers demonstrated the preparation of chiral 2D polymer crystal by photopolymerization of a single crystal of an enantiomorphic monomer composed of three photoreactive anthracene units bridged by two triazine motifs, forming a barrel-type structure.35 UV irradiation of polyhedral monomer single crystal with 465 nm can induce its photopolymerization to form polymer bulk crystal with a layered structure. This polymer bulk crystal can be easily exfoliated into single- or few-layer nanosheet in NMP or perfluorinated carboxylic acids by a method similar to that for the aforementioned 2D polymer nanosheet. The transformation between the monomer and polymer bulk crystal was reversible by UV irradiation and heating. Yang and co-workers first reported the preparation of atomically thin singlecrystalline 2D nanosheets of organic−inorganic hybrid perovskites with well-defined square shape by a solution method.48 In a typical process, the as-synthesized precursors of C4H9NH3Br and PbBr2 were dissolved in DMF with a high concentration, then diluted 100 times by a mixed DMF/chlorobenzene (1:1 in volume) solvent, and diluted 10 times by either chlorobenzene (CB) or mixed CB/acetonitrile (2:1 in volume) solvent again. After that, a small amount of the diluted solution (e.g., 10 μL) was dropped onto the cleaned Si/SiO2 substrate, which was preheated at 75 °C. After being dried for 10 min, 2D (C4H9NH3)2PbBr4 nanosheet was obtained on the Si/SiO2 substrate (Figure 20c,d).48 This procedure can be used for the preparation of ultrathin organic−inorganic hybrid perovskite nanosheets of other chloride, iodide, and alloyed derivatives.

sections.heading: 5. CHARACTERIZATION
sections.text:
Along with the rapid development of nanotechnology, some useful and powerful characterization techniques have been developed and/or identified for characterizing ultrathin 2D nanomaterials to uncover their composition, size, thickness, crystallinity, crystal phase, defects, oxidation states, and electronic states. Particularly, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials prepared by different synthetic methods possess different structural characteristics. Therefore, a clear and accurate characterization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials is of particular
importance in understanding the strong correlation between structural characteristics and properties or functionalities, as well as in guiding the rational design of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with desired structural features for a given application and figuring out the growth mechanism for the material synthesis. Until now, wide ranges of advanced characterization techniques, such as optical microscopy, SPM, scanning electron microscopy (SEM), transmission electron microscopy (TEM)/scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM), XAFS, XPS, and Raman spectroscopy, have been widely used for distinguishing ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. Given that each technique has its own advances and limitations, combining different characterization techniques is highly desirable to fully understand different structural features or properties of as-synthesized ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. It is also important to understand the underlying working principles and optimized conditions to collect reliable data from each technique. In this section, we aim to introduce a number of typical characterization techniques that have been widely used to characterize ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 5.1. Optical Microscopy
sections.text:
Visibility of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials under an ordinary optical microscope has greatly facilitated deeper study of their properties and applications because it rapidly provides information on location, shape, and thickness.98−100 This imaging method is based on the interference of reflected light at various interfaces. An optical contrast between the bare substrate and the ultrathin 2D nanomaterial is generated when the sample introduces a noticeable perturbation of optical path and opacity.98−100 Silicon covered with a thin layer of silicon dioxide (SiO2/Si) is the most frequently used substrate to support 2D nanomaterials. A portion of the incident light is transmitted while the other portion is reflected at each interface, as shown in Figure 21a.98 Depending on the thickness, absorption coefficients, refractive indexes differences as compared to silicon dioxide, and the wavelength of incident light, the intensity of collectively reflected light with respect to the interference varies with position. Many ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, for example, the mechanically exfoliated ones, have been observed in this manner, and few of them have been identified with monochromic light or silicon dioxide with continuously changed thicknesses. Initial attention was paid to graphene soon after the successful isolation of single-layer carbon sheets.98,613,614 Geim and co-workers found that 90 and 280 nm thick SiO2 are the most appropriate substrates for
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6248
graphene under white or green light illumination, as shown in Figure 21b.613 Discrepancies between the experimental results and calculation are probably due to the uncertainty of optical parameters of these ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, which are different from their bulk counterparts. However, empirical research on the contrast is already very helpful to study the emerging 2D semiconductors of which electronic and optoelectronic properties depend on the numbers of layers.615 To this end, several groups investigated the visibility of a few kinds of TMDs, such as MoS2, WSe2, and NbSe2, on SiO2/Si substrates with specific thicknesses.99,100,616 Figure 21c clearly shows distinctly different colors of MoS2 nanosheets with different layer numbers on a 90 nm SiO2/Si substrate. 100 Contrast values extracted from the color image enabled accurate identification of layer numbers up to 15.100
Considering the vastness of the library for the family of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials along with their continuous discoveries,617 limited data have been reported on the visibility of these nanomaterials. The method discussed above is readily applicable to other 2D nanomaterials with proper optical properties. Experienced researchers can easily identify the rough thickness of studied 2D nanomaterials according to their colors and contrast, although further characterization may be necessary to obtain an accurate value. However, most insulating 2D nanomaterials, such as h-BN, have a small refractive index. The contrast of monolayers and even few layers lack the contrast to be distinguished in the reflected light.

sections.heading: 5.2. Scanning Probe Microscopy
sections.text:
SPM is a powerful tool to study surface properties of materials with a high resolution.618 Topography, electrical screening, and electronic band structures of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials can be tackled through various interactions and careful interpretations. 5.2.1. Atomic Force Microscopy. Atomic force microscopy (AFM) is frequently utilized to measure the thickness of 2D nanomaterials. Although this method seems straightforward, it needs to be combined with other characterization methods such as optical contrast, Raman spectroscopy, and photoluminescence spectroscopy to accurately identify the layer numbers of layered 2D nanomaterials. Care should be taken because of the ultrathin nature of layered 2D nanomaterials. Their apparent thicknesses measured by AFM are easily interfered by the large chemical contrast between 2D nanomaterials and the surrounding substrates, confined water layer beneath the nanomaterials, and adsorbed contaminants on the surfaces.50,619,620 Discrepancies of thicknesses, especially for
the single layers, exist between theoretical and measured values. For example, measured heights of single-layer graphene on SiO2/Si substrates vary from 0.5 to 1.0 nm depending on the settings of AFM because of the chemical contrast. Furthermore, Xu et al. used single-layer graphene to visualize the water adlayer on the hydrophilic mica substrate, revealing the effect of adsorbed water layer (Figure 22a−c).619 The AFM heights of solution-processed 2D nanomaterials tend to be larger than the theoretical thicknesses because they are usually coated with ligands or nonvolatile solvents and often have a larger roughness. Figure 22d represents an AFM image of the MoS2 nanosheet on a Si/SiO2 substrate prepared through an electrochemical Li intercalation-assisted liquid exfoliationmethod.63 The average thickness of this nanosheet is approximately 1.0 nm, significantly larger than the theoretical value of 0.65 nm. AFM is also a powerful tool to study the degradation of many unstable 2D nanomaterials in air. The morphological change over time is used to assess the stability of these materials. For example, BP nanosheet degrades quickly at ambient conditions due to the chemical reaction between BP, oxygen, and the subsequent dissolution of the reation products. This degradation results in a noticeable morphological change in the surface roughness, from smooth to rough, with bubbles that can be easily distinguished by AFM.621 The irreversible degradation could be postponed or even prevented after these unstable 2D nanomaterials are protected by other stable materials, such as hBN, graphene, Al2O3, and AlOx. 621−624
5.2.2. Conductive Atomic Force Microscopy (CAFM). While AFM provides topographic information on ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, conductive AFM (CAFM), a variation of AFM, can be utilized to explore material conductivity with a high spatial resolution. Britnell et al. studied the tunneling resistivity of h-BN layers by using CAFM.625 The conductive tip acts as a top electrode, and the current tunneling from the bottom graphite electrode to the tip is measured (Figure 23a). The resistance map is quite uniform on each plateau without any spikes (Figure 23b,c). It means that there are minimum defects or pinholes, consolidating the fact that h-BN is a superior dielectric material for field effect devices based on 2D nanomaterials.310 In contrast, a similar setup revealed inhomogeneous local resistivity of MoS2 nanosheets, 626 consistent with the fact that there are a lot of defects such as sulfur vacancies on the surface of MoS2. A linear correlation is discovered between the resistivity and Schottky barrier height,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6249
demonstrating the dominating role of the defects in current injection. 5.2.3. Electrostatic Force Microscopy (EFM) and Kelvin Probe Force Microscopy (KPFM). The long-range electrostatic interaction between the conductive tip and the sample surface induces detectable changes in oscillation characteristics such as amplitude and phase. These changes are dependent on the local electrostatic potential of the sample surface. In this way, the detected changes assist to reveal the surface potentials and electric screening properties of the materials. These techniques such as EFM and KPFM are particularly interesting to study the interactions between 2D nanomaterials and substrates because of their ultrathin body and relatively weak screening effect of 2D nanomaterials.627−629 CastellanosGomez et al. studied the electrostatic screening effects in MoS2 nanosheets on Si/SiO2 substrates by using EFM. 627 The
conductive tip was lifted to a constant height above the sample surface, and the oscillation amplitude was measured while ramping the voltage applied to the tip.627 The maxima occur when the applied voltage counteracts the surface potential. Different voltages applied to the tip are needed to reach the maxima of oscillation amplitude when tested on MoS2 with different layer numbers because the surface potential of thinner MoS2 is easier to be modified by the charged impurities at the MoS2/SiO2 interfaces.
627 Systematic measurements demonstrate the dependence of surface potential on the thickness of MoS2. Besides charge impurities, other substrate effects such as intercalated water layer lead to spatially nonuniform surface potential. By mapping the surface potential at a constant tip voltage, a typical KPFM image is obtained. Figure 24 is an example illustration of water intercalation studied with AFM and KPFM.630 When the CVD-grown MoS2 on an Al2O3 substrate is exposed to air, progressive hydroxylation and hydration take place at the interfaces, resulting in the inhomogeneity of the surface potential (Figure 24c). The large work function shifts are believed to result from the charge transfer between the substrate and MoS2 (Figure 24f).
5.2.4. Scanning Tunneling Microscopy (STM) and Scanning Tunneling Spectroscopy (STS). STM and STS provide localized electron density of states besides atomically resolved surface morphologies. During the last two decades, STM and STS have been employed to study the electronic band structure and doping of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. These results are irreplaceable to reveal the quasi-particle band gap, defect- and gating-induced doping, localized metallic behavior, and band alignment of van der Waals heterostructures.631−634
Because tunneling conductance (dI/dV) is proportional to the local density of states, the quasi-particle band gap can be directly probed by analyzing the dI/dV−V spectra obtained by sweeping sample bias (V).635 Zhang et al. obtained a quasiparticle band gap of single-layer MoS2 to be around 2.15 eV. 636 In view of the 1.93 eV optical band gap measured by photoluminescence at the same temperature as STS experiments, they claim the exciton binding energy to be around 0.22
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6250
eV. By utilizing a similar method, Lu et al. measured the band gap of bulk MoS2 to be 1.3 eV, comparable to the value measured by photoluminescence.633 This distinct difference proves the excitonic nature of light−matter interaction in ultrathin 2D semiconductors. Edge regions of single-layer MoS2 were found to be metallic.636 It is consistent with earlier studies, which is highly valuable to identify the active sites of MoS2 as an electrochemical catalyst.637,638
The relative position of the Fermi level and the band edges defines the doping type of semiconductors. Lu et al. tracked the position evolution of Fermi level in MoS2 with gate voltages. 633 At zero gate voltage, the Fermi level lies below the conduction band edge, demonstrating the unintentional n-doping in MoS2. By applying positive (negative) gate voltage, the Fermi level is pushed into (away from) the conduction band. This process roughly depicts the switching of resistance in MoS2 metal− oxide−semiconductor field-effect transistors (MOSFETs). The switching mechanism of MoS2 FETs is much more complicated because the metal−semiconductor contacts play a significant role in the switching process as we will introduce later. It is therefore important to study the interaction, including chemical reaction and Fermi level pinning between ultrathin 2D semiconductors and metal contacts. McDonnell et al. found that the intrinsic defects in MoS2 pinned the Fermi levels of contact metals close to the conduction band regardless of the work functions of the metals (Ti, Au, or Pd) if the metal does not react with MoS2.
634 They also discovered that the position of the Fermi level varies a lot even at only tens of nanometers across, as shown in Figure 25. Because of the ease of access to MoS2 crystals and nanosheets along with their promising applications in electronics and optoelectronics, most of the SPM experiments
have been carried out on MoS2 (besides on graphene). Nevertheless, similar methods are being applied to other ultrathin 2D nanomaterials and their heteronanostructures too.639,640 Hill et al. examined the electronic structure of MoS2−WS2 heterostructures.641 Besides the type II band alignment between MoS2 and WS2, an interfacial band gap of 1.45 ± 0.06 eV was also observed. These results are consistent with the photovoltaic and photoluminescence results reported previously.642,643 Moreover, these reports also indicate that SPM continues to play a significant role in studying the morphological and electronic properties of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 5.3. Scanning Electron Microscopy
sections.text:
SEM is a widely used technique to characterize the morphology, topology, and detail surface structure of solid materials.644 Unlike the optical microscope, which has resolution limit in micrometers, SEM has a much higher spatial resolution due to the small de Broglie wavelength of electrons. In an SEM, a focused electron beam scanned across the sample surface. The inelastic scattering interaction between electrons and sample surface will generate secondary electrons near the sample surface within a few nanometers to few micrometers. Secondary electrons are detected by a scintillator grid detector, and the signal intensity is used to reconstruct a digital image. Currently, the voltage used to generate electrons in a SEM is about few kV (e.g., 5 kV), and resolution of about few nanometers can be achieved. SEM is used as a simple and fast technique to identify the morphology including size and shape and surface topology. For instance, Zhang and co-workers used the SEM to examine the lateral size of the ternary metal chalcogenide nanosheets (Ta2NiS5, deposited on a SiO2/Si substrate).
389 Even so, SEM normally needs to be combined with other characterization techniques, such as TEM and AFM, to obtain the full structural information on ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.

sections.heading: 5.4. Transmission Electron Microscopy/Scanning Transmission Electron Microscopy
sections.text:
TEM is a powerful technique to characterize the size, crystallinity, phase, exposed facets, and growth direction of a thin material.645 It is one of the most widely used techniques for characterization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials in the literature. Unlike SEM, electrons are transmitted through the thin sample, and the interaction signals of electrons transmitting from sample are collected to generate an image. Note that electrons in a TEM are generated from a high voltage (from 60 to 300 kV, normally used voltage is 200 kV) and thus have a shorter wavelength, resulting in a much higher resolution than that of SEM. It is worth pointing out that the electron irradiation of TEM might induce the decomposition or structure change of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. The damage of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials can be avoided by properly selecting a low accelerating voltage during the TEM measurement (e.g., 80 keV). Low-magnification TEM images can be used to examine the lateral size of nanosheets and roughly study the thickness. The lateral size of the exfoliated nanosheets can be precisely measured from the low-magnification TEM images. The thickness of nanosheets can be roughly evaluated from the contrast of TEM images. As known, low-magnification TEM images are normally collected under bright-field TEM mode, in which the contrast of a material is proportional to the thickness and the Z number of the material.646 Therefore, the thickness
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6251
can be roughly estimated from its contrast for the same material, where darker contrast indicates thicker thickness in the same TEM image. The exact thickness of nanosheets needs to be confirmed by other techniques, such as AFM, STEM, Raman spectroscopy, and photoluminescence spectroscopy. Because of their atomic thickness, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials normally give low contrast in TEM images. The crystallinity, phase, crystal orientation, and exposed crystal facets of nanomaterials can be explored by highresolution TEM (HRTEM) images combined with SAED patterns.646 The crystallinity of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials can be evaluated from the HRTEM images and corresponding SAED patterns. Note that diffraction patterns can also be measured at low magnification. Single-crystalline nanosheets give continuous lattice fringes with the same orientation and clear bright spots in SAED pattern images. Polycrystalline nanosheets give incontinuous lattice domains with random orientations and ring-like SAED patterns, while neither lattice fringes nor SAED pattern can be observed from amorphous nanosheets. For crystalline nanosheets, the exposed crystal facets can be confirmed by measuring the lattice distances from the HRTEM images. The growth direction of the nanosheets can also be identified by the HRTEM images and SAED patterns. For 2D metal chalcogenide heteronanostructures, SAED pattern is a more straightforward way to study the epitaxial growth effect. The two different crystals should have the same crystal orientation if they are epitaxially grown together. The SAED pattern can also be used to roughly identify the layer number (or thickness) of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials when combined with the simulation result of electron diffraction patterns. For example, Castellanos-Gomez and co-workers reported the usage of SAED patterns to count the layer number of exfoliated BP nanosheets.305 In addition, Zhang and co-workers used TEM to characterize the size, crystal phase, and growth orientation of the hcp Au nanosheet.284 As shown in Figure 26a, the low-magnification TEM image clearly shows the Au nanosheet has a regular square shape with an edge length of 200−500 nm.284 The measured lattice distances of 2.42 and 2.27 Å on a typical Au sheet correspond to the (002)h and (111)h planes of hcp Au crystal (Figure 26b).284 The corresponding diffraction spots of the
SEAD pattern are assignable to the hcp Au structure viewed along the [110]h direction (Figure 26c).
284 Figure 26d shows the SAED pattern taken after tilting the Au nanosheet by ∼19°, and the diffraction spots can be indexed to the hcp Au structure of [320]h zone axis, consistent with the theoretical angle between [320]h and [110]h, that is, 19°.
284 Therefore, combined with the XRD result, the Au square nanosheet can be concluded to crystallize in a unique hcp crystal structure rather than the common fcc structure. In the normal HRTEM mode, one is unable to directly image and localize different atoms in ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, thus making it difficult to identify the defects, vacancies, doping, and alloyed atoms in a nanosheet.647 The STEM technology provides a very powerful technique to image separate atoms in ultrathin 2D nanomaterials,648 especially after the introduction of aberration-corrected optics in this technique.649−651 Unlike the conventional TEM, focused electrons in the STEM mode are scanned over rather than transmitted to the sample in a raster, similar to that of electrons in the SEM. Significantly, atomic resolution images can be obtained in annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscope (ADF-STEM) images where the contrast of the atoms is directly proportional to the atomic number of the atoms. As a typical example, Krivanek and co-workers demonstrated the utilization of ADFSTEM in an aberration-corrected STEM to chemically identify all of the atoms in the single-layer h-BN nanosheet.652 The coexistence of boron, nitrogen, oxygen, and carbon in the single-layer h-BN nanosheet can be clearly observed, in which the carbon can replace the boron and nitrogen atoms and the oxygen can replace the nitrogen atom. Later, the ADF-STEM technique was further extended to identify the exact location of transition metal atoms and quantitatively calculate the atomic ratio in single-layer alloyed TMD nanosheets (e.g., MoxW1−xS2 and MoS2xSe2(1−x)). Suenaga and co-workers reported the discrimination of Mo and W atoms in the alloyed MoxW1−xS2 nanosheet.297 As shown in Figure 27a−c, both the Mo and W occupy the metal atom sites and the W atoms give brighter contrast due to a larger atomic number, while the S atoms are always paired in the trigonal lattice. Not only limited to chemical identification, ADF-STEM is also a compelling technique to characterize single-layer TMD nanosheets with
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6252
different crystal phases, which are difficult to distinguish in a normal HRTEM. Chhowalla and co-workers used the ADFSTEM method to identify the 2H phase and 1T phase domain in a single-layer MoS2 nanosheet.
653 As shown in Figure 27d−f, the atomic ADF-STEM image of the MoS2 nanosheet clearly shows the coexistence of 2H and 1T phases in a single MoS2 nanosheet with an atomically sharp phase boundary between the two phases.
The electron beam irradiation in a TEM is also a quite powerful way to induce the phase transformation on some ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, such as hcp Au and 2H phase MoS2 nanosheets. As a typical example, Zhang and co-workers demonstrated that the hcp Au nanosheet undergoes a phase transformation from the hcp phase to the twinned fcc phase under the electron bean irradiation for about ∼20 s.284 Meanwhile, the smooth Au square nanosheet gradually changed to porous nanosheet after the phase transformation. As another interesting example, Suenaga and co-workers reported that electron beam irradiation can also induce the phase transformation from 2H to 1T phase in the single-layer MoS2 nanosheet.108 It was found that the 2H phase was transformed into a new phase to form two atomic stripes under the irradiation of electron beam. The strip is composed of three to four constricted MoS2 zigzag chains, in which the Mo−Mo has a reduced distance. Therefore, the 1T phase was formed to release the strain induced by the packed atoms. Along with the continuous electron beam irradiation, the area of the 1T phase became larger to form a triangular shape, forming a single-layer MoS2 nanosheet with metallic 1T phase.

sections.heading: 5.5. X-ray Absorption Fine Structure Spectroscopy
sections.text:
XAFS, also known as X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), is a sensitive and powerful nondestructive spectroscopic technique to probe the structure characteristics of materials at atomic scale, such as the oxidation state, coordination chemistry, bond length, and species of the atoms. XAFS refers to the measurement of the X-ray absorption coefficient μ(E) as a function of the incident X-ray photons with energy E beyond the absorption edge E0 of a specific atom.654,655 The X-ray absorption spectrum includes two regimes: X-ray absorption near-edge spectroscopy (XANES) and extended X-ray absorption fine-structure spectroscopy (EXAFS). Specifically, XANES is sensitive to the oxidation state and coordination chemistry of the absorbing atom, while EXAFS is used to
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6253
determine the distances, coordination number, and neighboring species of the absorbing atom.654−656 Unlike powder X-ray diffraction, XAFS does not require long-range translational order and can be equally applied to measure amorphous and polycrystalline solids. The outstanding features of XAFS, such as the sensitivity to short-range order and element-specificity, make it attractive for probing the atomic environments surrounding a specific element in solid, liquid, and even gases.5,654,655 Nowadays, XAFS has been widely used for determining the atomic/electronic structure of nanomaterials.656
Ultrathin 2D nanosheets have atomic thickness with a high percentage of surface atoms, which is different from their 3D counterpart. XAFS is an efficient technique to probe the local atomic arrangements and electronic structures of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials.656 For instance, Xie and co-workers performed XAFS measurements to study the structural features of the freestanding single-layer ZnSe nanosheet that is four-atoms thick.530 The large area single-layer ZnSe nanosheet was fabricated by exfoliation of the lamellar hybrid Zn2Se2(pa) (pa = n-propylamine) intermediate, followed by a heat treatment to remove the pa molecules. In their experiments, three different samples, including bulk ZnSe, exfoliated single-layer ZnSe-pa, and clean single-layer ZnSe, were tested using EXAFS at both Zn and Se K-edges. As shown in Figure 28a, the Zn K-edge kχ(k) oscillation curves of exfoliated clean single-layer ZnSe diverged from that of the bulk counterpart and exfoliated single-layer ZnSe-pa, implying their different local atomic arrangement.530 Their differences were also revealed by the Rspace curves as shown in Figure 28b.530 It was suggested that the pa molecules induce the slight expansion of the surface Zn− Se bond lengths, but the next nearest Zn−Zn distances (3.85 Å) were contracted and the Se−Se distances (4.11 Å) were elongated, as compared to the bulk value (4.012 Å). Such distortion of the exfoliated single-layer ZnSe-pa and clean single-layer ZnSe is beneficial to decrease their surface energy and endow them with excellent stability as well as to induce unique electronic properties (Figure 28c).530 According to the XAFS structural parameters, the structural model of single-layer ZnSe is constructed with the distorted bond lengths and bond angles labeled accordingly in Figure 28d.530 The unique chemical and electronic structures of single-layer ZnSe give rise to enhanced solar water splitting efficiency and photostability when used as the photoelectrode in a photoelectrochemcial cell. As another example, the same group reported the characterization of a pits-confined artificial threeatomic-layer CeO2 nanosheet and studied the active catalytic centers for carbon monoxide oxidation.209 It was evidenced through XAFS that the thin CeO2 nanosheet with approximately 20% pits occupancy has abundant pit-surrounding cerium sites with an average coordination number of 4.6. Density-functional calculations suggested that the 4- and 5-fold coordinated pit-surrounding Ce sites play a key role in CO adsorption and O2 activation, which avoid catalytic poisoning and lower the activation barrier, thus giving rise to an excellent carbon monoxide catalytic ability.209
XAFS was also used to characterize the interactions between different components in 2D hybrid nanomaterials. Dai and coworkers studied the chemical and structure properties of Co3O4/N-rmGO hybrid, that is, Co3O4 nanocrystals supported on reduced mildly N-doped graphene oxide sheets (N-rmGO), and glean the interactions between Co3O4 and N-rmGO by using XANES.657 It was found that the carbon K-edge peak
intensity at ∼288 eV of Co3O4/N-rmGO increased as compared to N-rmGO, indicating the interaction between Co3O4 and rmGO with the possible formation of CO−O−C and Co−N−C bonds in the hybrid nanomaterial. The oxygen K-edge exhibited an obvious decrease in unoccupied O 2p−Co 3d hybrid state and the Co L-edge peak intensity increased, suggesting the formation of higher ionic Co−O bonding in the hybrid nanomaterial. The interactions between Co3O4 and graphene sheets may give rise to an enhanced electrocatalytic activity for ORR.

sections.heading: 5.6. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy
sections.text:
XPS is a powerful spectroscopic technique that has been widely used for characterization of nanomaterials.658 An XPS spectrum represents the number of detected electrons as a function of the binding energy of the detected electrons within a material when it is exposed to a beam of X-rays. The elemental composition can be easily identified within a material because each element has its own characteristic binding energy peaks. The location and shape of peaks for each element are very sensitive to the electron configuration of the electrons within the atoms, making it very effective to analyze the chemical composition, surface contamination, electronic state, and local bonding of atom of a material. XPS is a surface-sensitive technique and only can measure the material surface within 10 nm. Fortunately, this is not an issue for ultrathin 2D nanomaterials because their thicknesses are normally less than 5 nm. XPS not only can qualitatively analyze the elemental compositions but also can be used to quantitatively determine the chemical composition within a material, considering that XPS has been identified as a useful and reliable technique for characterization of a vast number of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. In most cases, XPS was used as one of the major techniques to identify the elemental compositions and surface oxidation states of as-prepared ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. Zhang and coworkers used XPS to study the exfoliated single-layer Ta2NiS5 nanosheet.389 In high-resolution XPS spectra, Ta 4f, Ni 2p, and S 2p signals can be clearly observed for the exfoliated Ta2NiS5 nanosheet, indicating the unchanged elemental composition after exfoliation. It was found that, although single-layer nanosheet can be well exfoliated from its layered bulk crystal, the single-layer Ta2NiS5 nanosheet was partially oxidized during the exfoliation process because oxidation peaks of TaOx and NiOx were clearly observed both in the high-resolution XPS Ta 4f and Ni 2p spectra.389 Ruoff and co-workers used XPS to qualitatively and quantitatively analyze the oxygen-containing groups on GO before and after reduction.116 The highresolution XPS C 1s spectrum of GO gave a considerable degree of oxidation with four components corresponding to carbon atoms in different functional groups, that is, the nonoxygenated ring of C, the C in C−O bonds, the carbonyl C, and the carboxylate carbon (O−C@O). In contrast, after reduction, the peak intensities of these oxygen-containing functional groups in the XPS spectrum of rGO significantly decreased, although these peaks still can be observed. This result indicated that, after reduction, most of the oxygencontaining groups were removed from the GO surface, although not completely. XPS not only can be used to qualitatively identify the different types of functional groups, but also to quantitatively analyze the content of each functional group on the GO surface, thus determining the reduction degree of GO nanosheet. By careful deconvolution of the peaks and calculation of the peak areas, the content of each oxygen-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6254
containing functional group of GO nanosheets can be easily calculated from its high-resolution C 1s XPS spectrum. As another typical example, Li and co-workers used XPS to
qualitatively and quantitatively monitor the composition changes during the selenization of MoS2 nanosheet by the CVD method to prepare alloyed MoS2xSe2(1−x) nanosheets. 659 The as-grown MoS2 nanosheet gives two characteristic peaks in the high-resolution XPS Mo 3d (232.5 and 229.3 eV) and S 2p (163.3 and 162.1 eV) spectra, corresponding to the 2H phase
MoS2. Meanwhile, the high resolution also shows two peaks at 232.4 and 235.6 eV that are assigned to MoO3.
