Additional peaks at 55.3 and 54.5 eV are assignable to Se 3p of MoSe2 and can be observed after selenization of the MoS2 at 600 °C. The doublets peaks belonging to Se 3p of MoSe2 gradually become more obvious, and the S 2p peaks of MoS2 become less prominent when the selenization temperature was further increased. The MoS2 was fully transformed into MoSe2 when it was selenized at 900 °C, and only the signals from MoSe2 were
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6255
detected in the XPS spectra. The whole XPS analyses combined with the optical band gap evolution revealed that the MoS2 was gradually converted into MoS2xSe2(1−x) and finally MoSe2 with the increasing of the selenization temperature. It is worth pointing out that the oxidation peaks are not observed after the high-temperature selenization process. The content of MoSe2 in the system after the selenization process at different temperature can be calculated from the XPS spectra. It was estimated that the percentage of MoSe2 was about 14.5%, 73.8%, 95%, and 100% at 600, 700, 800, and 900 °C, respectively. Intriguingly, not only limited to compositions and oxidations, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with different crystal phases can be also identified and distinguished by XPS. As a typical example, Chhowalla and co-workers used XPS to identify the different phases and quantitatively calculate the concentration of each phase in ultrathin 2D TMD nanosheets, such as MoS2 and WS2.
660,661 As discussed above, the Li intercalation into layered bulk MoS2 crystal can induce the phase transformation from the semiconducting 2H phase to metallic 1T phase due to the electron transfer from the butyl to MoS2, resulting in the coexistence of 2H and 1T phases in the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet (Figure 29a).211,660 As shown in Figure 29b, the deconvolution of Mo 3d and S 2p peaks revealed peaks that belong to 2H-MoS2 and additional peaks at lower binding energies, shifted by 0.9 eV with respect to the 2H-MoS2 peaks.660 It was suggested that the peaks at lower binding energies are assignable to the 1T-MoS2, indicating the rise of metallic 1T phase and the coexistence of 2H and 1T phases in the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet. Note that thermal annealing of the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet at mild temperature can induce the restoration of 2H phase from 1T phase. From that experiment, they also studied the phase compositions at different annealing temperatures by XPS. What was found is that the intensity of 1T phase peaks in both the Mo 3d and the S 2p decreased along with the increase of the annealing temperature from 100 to 300 °C.660 The phase concentration can be also calculated by integrating the XPS spectra. The calculated result indicates that the concentration of the 1T phase is about 50% in the as-exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet.
602 The concentration of the 1T phase decreased with the increase of annealing temperature. The MoS2 nanosheet only has 5% 1T phase after annealing at 300 °C.660

sections.heading: 5.7. Raman Spectroscopy
sections.text:
Raman spectroscopy, a fast and nondestructive characterization method, provides structural and electronic information with high spectral as well as spatial resolution.122 Extending from the success in characterizing graphene,120,662,663 Raman spectros-
copy has been employed to reveal the number of layers, crystalline orientation and phases, strain and doping effects, and van der Waals coupling of various ultrathin 2D nanomaterials and their heteronanostructures. In this section, we will discuss the recent phenomenological discoveries in characterizing ultrathin 2D nanomaterials by using Raman spectroscopy. Lee et al. reported the Raman scattering properties of singleand few-layer MoS2, which is the first example of Raman study on ultrathin 2D TMDs (Figure 30).664 Representative Raman spectra of single- to few-layer and bulk MoS2 are shown in Figure 30a. Two strong peaks assigned to in-plane (E12g) and out-of-plane (A1g) vibrations are observed. A clear shift of peak positions as a function of layer numbers for each vibrational mode is also shown in Figure 30b. E12g peaks red shift while A1g peaks blue shift with increasing thickness of MoS2. According to the conventional model, E12g and A1g peaks are both expected to blue shift for thicker layers because of additional interlayer van der Waals interactions. The anomalous behavior of the E12g peaks is attributed to additional interlayer interactions. This opposite shift leads to a larger frequency difference between E12g and A1g peaks for thicker MoS2 layers, which can be used as an indication of the number of layers. Figure 30c,d shows the mapping with the peak frequencies of E12g and A1g modes, respectively. Uniform color on the same layer and strong contrast between different layers are observed, consistent with the measurement of thicknesses by using AFM.664 Because of the off-resonance excitation, normal spectrometers cannot be used to detect the vibrational modes of 2D nanomaterials. The lack of enough filtering of Rayleigh light makes it hard to detect the breathing/shear modes. Several specific studies reveal that the evolution of these “hidden” modes is also useful in identifying the numbers of layers.121,665
Layered 2D nanomaterials, such as BP132,666 and ReS2, 667,668 with strong in-plane anisotropy exhibit novel optical and electronic properties, such as anisotropic electronic conductivities and mobilities. It is therefore highly required to identify the crystalline orientation rapidly and nondestructively for both research and application objectives. Angle-resolved polarized Raman spectroscopy can fulfill these requirements. Taking BP as an example, its crystal orientation can be revealed by analyzing the evolution of characteristic Ag 1, B2g, and Ag 2 peaks dependent on the polarization angle of excitation laser light and rotation angle of the sample.669 When collected with sample direction, intensities of Ag 1 and Ag 2 peaks are strongest at α = 0°/180° and are forbidden at α = 90°, while the B2g peaks show the opposite trend. Rotating the sample changes this behavior, but the peak intensities still change periodically with polarization angles. Combining the effects of polarization angles and
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6256
rotation angles of the sample to the Raman peak intensities, one can distinguish the crystalline orientation of BP nanosheets. A similar strategy has been successfully applied to other intrinsically anisotropic 2D nanomaterials such as ReS2. 670,671
Because of the variety of atomic arrangements and stacking orders, layered TMDs exhibit complex crystal structures with polymorphs. Single-layer MoS2 has two types of polymorphs, 1T phase with octahedral coordination and 1H phase with trigonal prismatic coordination. Depending on the stacking orders, stacking 1H-MoS2 results in a 2H or 3R phase. Chemically transformed 1T-MoS2 has been proven to have perfect homogeneous contacts to 2H-MoS2 in high-performance field-effect transistors.653 Cho et al. used a laser to induce phase transformation of 2H MoTe2.
672 The obtained 1T′MoTe2 also shows great potential as contact materials to 2HMoTe2. These transformations are monitored by using photoemission spectroscopy, photoluminescence mapping, and Raman spectroscopy. Figure 31 shows the Raman spectra of MoS2 and MoTe2 with different phases. Transformed phases (1T-MoS2 and 1T′-MoTe2) display new peaks, which can be assigned to their respective lattice vibrational modes. In other words, the Raman spectra can be used as fingerprints to distinguish the crystal phases. Raman spectroscopy has also been utilized to probe external perturbations, such as strain673 and doping effects674 in ultrathin 2D nanomaterials. Subtle changes of Raman peak positions and intensities are observed when gradually stretching or applying gate voltages to the MoS2 nanosheet. Besides manually applied disturbance, unintentional substrate effects675,676 and environmental effects677 may also lead to dielectric or doping changes in ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, resulting in slight shifts of Raman peaks. These effects mostly exist simultaneously, and, hence, care should be taken when interpreting the changes of Raman spectra.

sections.heading: 6. APPLICATIONS
sections.text: Because of their 2D structural characteristics, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have exhibited unique physical, electronic, chemical, and optical properties for potentially a wide spectra of applications. The diverse families of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials also display versatile compositions and properties, offering an immense selection of materials for a given application. To name a few, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have been proven to be compelling in a variety of applications, including electronics/optoelectronics, catalysis, energy storage and conversion, water remediation, sensors, biomedicine, etc. In this section, we summarize the recent process on the utilization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials in a number of applications, focusing on the electronic and optoelectronic devices, electrocatalysis, batteries, supercapacitors, solar cells, photocatalysis, and sensing platforms.

sections.heading: 6.1. Electronic/Optoelectronic Devices
sections.text:
In the last two decades, 1D nanomaterials, specifically carbon nanotubes (CNTs) and silicon nanowires, have drawn great attention in the pursuit of new generation of electronics for applications ranging from drive circuits to active matrixes and high-performance microprocessors.678,679 Yet, ever since the discovery of graphene, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have replaced 1D nanomaterials as the center of this pursuit.125 Although extensive studies have shown the great promise of graphene with ultrahigh electron mobility, its electronic application is hindered by the lack of bandgap.3 As an alternative, the emerging 2D semiconducting nanomaterials, such as TMD and BP nanosheets, offer solution through their relatively high carrier mobility and tunable band structures.125 Ultrathin 2D semiconductors with single- to few-layer thickness have become the focus of nanoelectronic research because of their intriguing mechanical and electronic properties.125,126,128,680−682 The ultrathin nature of these 2D semiconductors makes them resistant to short-channel effects while
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6257
having high flexibility. Besides, the surfaces of layered 2D nanomaterials are free of dangling bond, which alleviates the surface scattering effects. Because of these unique properties, many 2D semiconductors, including MoS2, MoSe2, MoTe2, WS2, WSe2, GaTe, and BP, have been explored in different electronic and optoelectronic applications. In the following section, we focus on the introduction of the recent advances in ultrathin 2D nanomaterials for electronics and optoelectronics, categorized by the material’s type. 6.1.1. Ultrathin 2D TMDs. Bulk TMDs have been studied for decades; however, this class of materials only attracted interest for electronic applications in the past few years.128 Most TMDs are metal or semimetal with very small bandgaps, while others are semiconducting TMDs, such as MoS2, MoSe2, WS2, and WSe2, holding great potential in electronics and optoelectronics.16 Because of the similarity of device physics and performance, MoS2 nanosheet is used as a representative example for the large varieties in the TMD family. 6.1.1.1. MoS2-Based FETs. MoS2 transistor was studied as early as in 2005.50 It started to receive critical attention in 2011 after the demonstration of its on/off ratio, which can be as high as 108, and room-temperature mobility, exceeding 100 cm2 V−1 s−1.129 Atomically thin MoS2 is considered as a particularly promising material for next-generation electronics, due to its large bandgap, excellent chemical and thermal stability, as well as superior resistance to short-channel effect. Initial studies focused on the mechanically exfoliated MoS2 with high crystal quality and few defects. Figure 32a shows a mechanically exfoliated single-layer MoS2 on the SiO2 susbstrate. The corresponding high-performance and top-gate FET with singlelayer MoS2 as the channel, as shown in Figure 32b, demonstrates an ultrahigh on/off ratio exceeding 108.129 By further exploring the resistance of MoS2 to short-channel effect, Javay and co-workers recently demontrated the fabrication of
ultrashort-channel MoS2 FET with 1 nm gate length by using a single-walled carbon nanotube (SWCNT) as the gate electrode.683 Figure 32c schematically illustrated the MoS2FET with a SWCNT as the back gate. Figure 32d shows the false-colored SEM image of the actual device. The ultrashort channel transistor exhibits excellent switching characteristics with near-ideal subthreshhold swing of 65 mV/dec, approaching the theoretical limit.683 Fully integrated multistage circuits entirely assembled on few-layer MoS2 are also reported, putting it one-step closer for replacing silicon’s place in conventional electronics.684 This report impressively demonstrated the integration of an inverter, a NAND gate, a static random access memory, and a five-stage ring oscillator on bilayer MoS2 flakes. Many efforts have been devoted to exploring the electronic properties and optimizing the performance of MoS2 transistors. Strategies including chemical doping,685,686 channel suspending,687,688 strain engineering,689 and chemical repair of S vacancy690 have all been proposed and studied to enhance the performance of MoS2 nanosheet-based transistors. Doping the channel with inorganic or organic molecules is an effective way to tune and enhance the performance of MoS2 transistors. 685 Suspension of MoS2 in electrolyte-gating can reach gate coupling efficiency up to 4.6 × 1013 cm−2 V−1, providing a unique platform to study the metal−insulator transition of MoS2.
688 The 2D nature makes MoS2 a perfect candidate for flexible electronics.691−694 As shown in Figure 33a, a flexible transistor was fabricated on monolayer MoS2 with few-layer hBN as supporting substrate on polyethylene naphthala.691 The atomically thin MoS2 channel, h-BN dielectric, and graphene bottom-gate make the device perfectly transparent and flexible. The flexible device showed an on/off ratio over 104, mobility of 45 cm2 V−1 s−1, low operation gate-voltage below 10 V, and minimal influence under different strain (Figure 33b).691 By using a self-aligned gate, few-layer MoS2 transistor on polymer
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6258
substrate showed superior performance, such as the intrinsic gain over 30, an intrinsic cutoff frequency f T up to 42 GHz, and a maximum oscillation frequency fMAX up to 50 GHz. 694
Dielectric engineering has also been proposed to improve the carrier transport in 2D semiconducting TMD-based transistors. High-k dielectrics damp the scattering of charged impurities, which has been tested both theoretically and experimentally.695,696 Consistent with previous reports about semiconducting nanotubes and nanowires, covering MoS2 with HfO2 or Al2O3 increases the mobilities of MoS2. 697−699 Covering the transistors with a layer of insulator also encapsulates the devices and protects them from the atmospheric condition, further promoting a stable operation for the device because oxygen and water molecules in the atmosphere are partially responsible for the large hysteresis in 2D semiconducting TMD-based FETs.700 Charges trapped at the interfaces between 2D semiconductor and the oxide dielectrics are another source of the hysteresis.701 The operation can be further stabilized and enhanced by encapsulating 2D semiconductors with dangling-bond-free hBN at both sides, which will be further discussed in the h-BN section.702,703
Other than as candidates for future electronics, 2D semiconducting TMD-based transistors also found applications in chemical sensing479,704−707 and memory devices.708−710 MoS2 transistor has been used to detect protein with supreme sensitivity beyond capability of graphene transistors.707 Atomic layer deposition (ALD) AlOx passivation is required to prevent the instability of MoS2 channel and the interface of metal contact in aqueous environments. This Schottky contact of MoS2/metal is later explored for highly sensitive gas detection.479 With the ever-developing synthesis and lithography technique of MoS2 thin-film, MoS2-based integrated electronic and optoelectronic circuits can be anticipated. A gate-tunable memristor was demonstrated on the CVD-grown MoS2 nanosheet. The mechanism of the conductance change is believed to be the migration of the grain boundary of singlelayer MoS2 under high bias voltage. 710
6.1.1.2. MoS2-Based Optoelectronic Devices. The bandgap of MoS2 varies from 1.2 eV of indirect bandgap in multilayer to 1.9 eV of direct bandgap in a single layer. Similar layerdependence in bandstructure is also observed for other 2D TMD semiconductors, such as MoSe2, WSe2, and WS2. This unique property makes single-layer TMD semiconductors very attractive in optoelectronics. This section focuses on the phototransistors/photodetectors, while all of the vertical junction devices will be discussed in the following section of van der Waals heterostructures. Monolayer MoS2 is a direct-bandgap semiconductor due to quantum-mechanical confinement with large absorption coefficiency,128 making it popular in optoelectronics. Zhang and co-workers first reported the single-layer MoS2-based phototransistor prepared by the micromechanical cleavage method.130 The device showed much higher photosensitivity than the graphene-based phototransistor. A later study by Kis and co-workers demonstrated that a photodetector based on mechanically exfoliated MoS2 could achieve a maximum external photoresponsivity of 880 AW−1.711 Encapsulating the MoS2 transistor in HfO2 further enhanced the performance to 104 AW−1 and the response time to 10 ms.712
6.1.1.3. In Situ Probing the Phase Transition of TMDs. Another interesting application of the various 2D electronic devices is to probe the physical and chemical properties of 2D
TMD nanomaterials in electrolytes. Similar to graphene,713 the electrolyte-gate transistor was used to induce the lithium intercalation in MoS2 thin-flakes to study the in situ phase transition and the resulted change in conductance and transparency.714 The concept was also applied on other 2D TMD nanosheets, such as 1T-TaS2, to monitor the phase transition in situ.715 In this setup, an electrolyte-gate was used to initiate the intercalation of lithium ions into 1T-TaS2 thinflakes. The phase transition is monitored by the change of the channel conductance during the intercalation. The intercalation alters the energetics of various charge-ordered states in 1T-TaS2 and produces a series of phase transitions at room temperature and low temperature.
6.1.1.4. Engineering of the Electrical Contact. The electrical contact to 2D TMD semiconductors is particularly challenging at the current stage of research.716 Large contact resistance and Schottky barrier at the metal/TMD interface significantly deteriorated the charge injection, therefore limiting the current and carrier mobility of the devices.716 Several methods have been proposed and experimentally demonstrated to solve this issue. Inspired by the conventional CMOS technologies, heavy doping at the contact region of 2D TMD nanosheets by metal ions, inorganics, and organic/biomolecules can efficiently lower the contact barrier and contact resistance.716 High-performance single-layer WSe2 transistor was obtained with NO2 doped electrical contact, reaching a mobility of 250 cm2 V−1 s−1.717 Phase engineering is another promising way to reduce the contact resistance in 2D semiconducting TMD-based transistors.653,672 The phase transition from pristine 2H to 1T significantly alters their electronic state from semiconducting to metallic. This concept was first demonstrated on CVD-grown MoS2 monolayer by chemical treatment of the metal contact area with nbutyllithium.653 The 1T contact allows ohmic contact to the MoS2 channel, evident by the linear Ids−Vds curves under gate modulation from −30 to 30 V (Figure 33c,d).653 Alternatively, a laser-induced phase transition from semiconducting 2H to metallic 1T phase has also been demonstrated in MoTe2, achieving high current mobility exceeding 250 cm2 V−1 s−1.672 Inserting graphene in the metal/semiconductor junction has shown low ohmic contact resistance.718 van der Waals contact using single-layer graphene shows exceptional good contact toward MoS2.
703,719,720 The gate-tunable graphene electrode leads to a nearly perfect band alignment with MoS2 with near zero contact barrier and ohmic contact at cryogenic temperatures.719 Record high Hall mobility of 34 000 cm2 V−1 s−1 and field-effect mobility of 1300 cm2 V−1 s−1are reported for fewlayer MoS2 transistor at low temperature. 703,720
6.1.1.5. Large-Area Synthesis of TMDs. Most of the aforementioned results are based on single-crystalline highquality single- or few-layer TMD nanosheets obtained by the mechanical cleavage method. Yet, scaling up the synthesis of TMDs remains another major challenge for broad electronic applications. The CVD method is still the most popular and effective method to large-scale synthesis of TMD thin films.81 The initial transistor based on the CVD-grown thin-film merely showed mobility of 0.02 cm2 V−1 S−1, far below the value of the mechanically exfoliated MoS2-based transistor. Many efforts have been devoted to improving the CVD method to grow high-quality MoS2 thin-film with mobility ranges from ∼0.1 to ∼20 cm2 V−1 S1−.478,721 The current status of CVD-grown MoS2-based transistors can even exceed the mechanically exfoliated MoS2 counterparts with room-temperature mobility
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6259
reaching 200 cm2 V−1 S−1.722 Although showing promising device performance, the aforementioned MoS2 are still very fragmental and incontrollable to meet the requirement for integrated circuits. Only until recently wafer-scale monolayer MoS2 thin-film has been prepared by the metal−organic CVD. Transistor array on a 4-in. wafer-scale was obtained with high mobility and excellent spatial homogeneity over the entire film.451
6.1.2. Ultrathin 2D BP Nanosheets. 6.1.2.1. BP-Based FETs. BP, a rare allotrope of phosphorus, has gained interest as an alternative to 2D semiconducting TMD nanosheets. Similar to TMD materials, BP is also formed by van der Waals stacking of its monolayers, known as phosphorene. BP possessed many exceptional electronic properties, such as high-theoretical mobility up to 10 000 cm2 V−1 S−1, tunable direct bandgap, and anisotropic transport.38 BP is primarily a p-type 2D semiconductor, which makes it a particularly useful building block for 2D electronics because most TMDs are n-type semiconductors.126 The first BP transistor was reported in 2014 based on a few-layer BP nanosheet obtained by the micromechanical cleavage method.132 The charge-carrier mobility was found to be thickness dependent and peaked at 1000 cm2 V−1 S−1 for the 10 nm thick BP nanosheet. The follow-up works further explored the electronic properties of BP transistor using gate-dielectric tuning,723 doped contact,724 and ultrashort channel.725
6.1.2.2. BP-Based Optoelectronics. BP is of particular interest in optoelectronics due to its direct bandgap existing across all thicknesses. The bandgap of BP shows the strong thickness dependence from 0.3 eV for the bulk BP to 1.7−2.1 eV for the single-layer BP depending on the dielectric environment.354 BP transistor with graphene as transparent top-gate showed high photoresponsivity up to 657 mAW−1 with a high response bandwidth exceeding 3 GHz.726 The p−n diode based on BP/MoS2 heterostructure has shown a maximum photoresponsivity of 418 mAW−1 with an external quantum efficiency of 0.3%.727
6.1.2.3. Preservation of BP in Electronics. The stabilization of BP nanosheets remains a major challenge because it is easily degraded in ambient condition with the presence of oxygen and water. Encapsulation is still an effective way to prevent BP transistor from ambient degradation.621,623,728 Atomic layer deposition of AlOx overlayer on BP channel suppresses the degradation and maintains a high mobility and on/off ratio over
2 weeks.621 An improvement to the oxide passivation is later developed using h-BN encapsulation. Dry-transfer method is used to sandwich single layer BP between two h-BN layers with ultraclean van der Waals interfaces.623 The sandwich structure is thermally stable over 500 °C, as compared to 350 °C for the normal BP, allowing annealing at high temperature, which further enhances the device performance. The encapsulated transistor shows impressive room-temperature mobility over 1300 cm2 V−1 s−1 with no change in device output over a week. Hersam and co-workers demonstrated that the exfoliated BP nanosheets can be stabilized by covalent aryl diazonium functionalization through the formation of phosphorus−carbon bonds.729 It was found that the functionalized BP nanosheets did show obvious degradation even after 3 weeks of ambient exposure.729 The covalent surface modification of BP nanosheets can give rise to a strong, tunable p-type doping effect, yielding a field-effect transistor with much enhanced carrier mobility and on/off current ratio.
6.1.3. Ultrathin 2D h-BN Nanosheets. Ultrathin 2D h-BN nanosheet is a chemically inert 2D nanomaterial with a bandgap above 5.9 eV,730 making it a nearly ideal dielectric material in many 2D electronic and optoelectronic systems. It is called “white graphene” due to its multifunction and huge potential in future electronics. Early studies have utilized the defect-free and ultraflat nature of h-BN as 2D substrates for high-performance transistors.310 h-BN has thus been extensively studied as the tunneling junction,625,731 gate dielectric,692 and electrical packaging.702,732,733 Being the only insulator in the current family of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, h-BN has become an essential building block in many 2D nanomaterial-based electronic applications.
6.1.3.1. h-BN as the Dielectric Material. The dielectric nature of the h-BN nanosheet was first probed on metal/ insulator/metal structure using graphene as the electrical contact.625 This early study proved h-BN to be a defect-free dielectric with a high breakdown field, showing its potential in high-quality tunneling barrier, and dielectric layer in FETs. The lateral junction of graphene/h-BN also confirms the insulating nature of h-BN for atomically thin electrical circuits.734 By utilizing the van der Waals stacking, many tunneling devices based on h-BN nanosheet with vertical charge transport were reported. The first field-effect tunneling transistor was reported using graphene/h-BN/graphene heterojunction with the atomically thin h-BN acting as the vertical transport barrier.735 This
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6260
work led to the flourishing of various vertical transistors and van der Waals heterostructures based on 2D nanomaterials, where the insulating h-BN plays a key role as tunneling barrier and electrical encapsulation. These works will be further discussed in the section related to van der Waals heterostructures below. 6.1.3.2. h-BN as 2D Supporting Substrate and Electrical Encapsulation. The h-BN nanosheet has an atomically smooth surface and is relatively free of dangling bond and charge trap, making it an ideal supporting platform for 2D electronics. Graphene transistor on h-BN substrate was first demonstrated in 2010, showing an order of magnitude improvement in mobility and carrier inhomogeneities.310 Although it is very challenging to fabricate, the ultraclean interface not only significantly enhances the device performance, but also allows for studying the fundamental physics of the encapsulated 2D semiconductors or heterostructures. Further encapsulating graphene between two h-BN layers allows the observation of ballistic transport at a micrometer scale for a wide range of carrier concentrations.732 The main reason behind the enhancement in device performance is the defect-free interface with minimal charge traps, along with a perfect insulation from ambient condition. The author further indicated that, although showing similar enhancement, the encapsulation of h-BN is superior to that of suspended transistors in terms of fabrication and device stability.736 By combining the h-BN encapsulation with 1D electrical contact, graphene transistors achieved ballistic transport with record mobility of 1 000 000 cm2 V−1 s−1.733 Figure 34a shows the graphene transistor encapsulated in two h-BN layers with the 1D electrical contact at the atomicsharp edge with ultraclean van der Waals interface clearly shown in the TEM cross-section image in Figure 34b. A similar concept has been proven to efficiently enhance the electronic performance of other semiconducting 2D nanomaterials, such as MoS2 and WSe2.
702,737 Note that this method is particularly useful to fabricate and preserve electronic devices based on chemically unstable 2D nanomaterials, such as BP623 and layered organohalide perovskites.738 In addition, the h-BN with 2D nature functions perfectly as flexible substrates.191,691,739
6.1.4. van der Waals Heterostructures. van der Waals (vdW) heterostructures are based on the vertical stacking of 2D building blocks by van der Waals force to realize unusual properties and exceptional performance.740 It evolves from the enormous 2D source nanomaterials, representing the infinite possibility of 2D nanomaterials in future electronics. vdW heterostructures rely on transfer techniques using van der Waals stacking of various 2D building blocks. The state-of-theart method for preparation of vdW heterostructures is drytransfer. As a method, it is eliminating the contamination and impurity at the van der Waals gaps, allowing atomic-sharp interfaces, and leading to ultrahigh performance as well as probing the fundamental physics in complex 2D systems.
6.1.4.1. vdW Heterostructure-Based Vertical Transistors. The first noticeable example of vdW heterostructures traced back to the 2011, on the vertically stacked heterostructure of double layer graphene.741 Meanwhile, pioneer works from Samsung in 2012 introduced a vertical barristor (transistor) based on the vertical junction of graphene/silicon.742 Figure 35a shows the schematic illustration of the graphene/silicon heterojunction modulated by the top-gate on graphene.742 The Schottky barrier at the graphene/silicon interface can be tuned by top-gate on graphene. As shown in Figure 35b, the graphene device showed an on−off ratio exceeding 105 (minimal requirement for logic circuits) with gate-modulation from −5 to +5 V, which is beyond the reach of planar transistors.742 In the same year, tunneling transistor based on graphene/h-BN/ graphene heterojunction was demonstrated with an on/off ratio as high as 104.735 These works lead to the development of vertical heterojunctions based on various 2D materials, such as the graphene/WS2 heterojunction on the h-BN support.
743 In this device, the combination of tunneling and thermionic contributes to an on/off ratio of 106. This work also demonstrates the high flexibility of the hybrid device, due to the thin and flexible nature of its 2D building blocks. Many efforts have been devoted to achieve the large-scale synthesis of vdW heterostructures by CVD method with only limited success so far.513,515,520,523,744 Lateral p−n junctions of MoS2/WSe2 and WS2/WSe2 were first reported using CVD-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6261
growth by in situ modulation of the vapor-phase reactant.511 The more challenging vertical heterostructure from WS2/MoS2 monolayer has been directly synthesized via control of growth temperature.515 Figure 35c shows that the scheme of the bilayer heterostructure consists of WS2/MoS2 monolayer.
515 The synthesis can be realized in large scale on silicon oxide wafer with uniform size and structure (Figure 35d).515 The p−n junction showed an atomically sharp interface with strong localized photoluminescence enhancement and diode-like behavior. The electronic performance of the CVD-grown heterojunction is currently lagging far behind the demonstration on mechanical exfoliation method and still requires further exploration as well as optimization. 6.1.4.2. vdW Heterostructure-Based Optoelectronic Devices. vdW heterostructures gain intense interest in optoelectronics due to unique light−matter interaction.745,746 Specifically, the p−n junctions based on vdW heterostructures have shown exceptional performance in photodiode and photodetector,727,747−750 electroluminescence,751−753 and photovoltaics.754
The graphene/silicon junction, structurally similar to the vertical transistor reported by Samsung, was used as a highly efficient photodiode and photodetector.755 Further integrating graphene into a silicon optical waveguide reached extreme
photoresponsivity with significantly enhanced graphene−light interaction.747 More complex vdW heterostructures, such as graphene/WSe2/graphene encapsulated in h-BN, were reported to reach an ultrashort response time down to 5.5 pS with internal quantum efficiency over 70%.748
The first optoelectronic device based on vdW heterostructure was reported in 2013 on graphene/WS2 stacks. Strong light− matter interaction was observed with enhanced photon absorption and electron−hole creation.756 The heterojunction proved an exciting hypothesis for flexible photovoltaic with an external quantum efficiency of above 30%. The concept was further improved by introducing an MoS2/graphene heterojunction with an external quantum efficiency over 50%.757 Atomic level p−n junction was first demonstrated on a junction of MoS2/WSe2 monolayers.
758 The p−n interface shows gatetunable diode-like rectification and photovoltaic response across the whole interface. Light generating and harvesting was also reported from p−n junction of bulk semiconductor/ TMD semiconductor.759 In this case, the p-type silicon/n-type MoS2 heterojunction can function as light emitting diode as well as solar cells. Electroluminescence is also observed in a GaN/Al2O3/MoS2 heterojunction.
752 Direct band gap emission was observed in multilayer MoS2 due to the electrical-fieldinduced redistribution from indirect bandgap to direct bandgap.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6262
LED that is fully based on 2D materials was reported subsequently from complex stacking between graphene, h-BN, and different TMD semiconductors.753 Figure 35e shows the delicate van der Waals stacking of MoS2, graphene, and h-BN in forming an artificial superlattice. Tunable emission with extrinsic quantum efficiency of 10% is reached by engineering the quantum well on the basis of this artificial supperlattice at atomic precision.

sections.heading: 6.2. Electrocatalysis
sections.text:
The intriguing structural and electronic properties as well as the intrinsic features of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials (e.g., ultrahigh surface area and tunable engineered structures) open their place in numerous potential applications for electrocatalysis. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with a variety of compositions have been prepared by various well-developed methods. Correspondingly, these ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have been widely explored as electrocatalysts in several significant electrochemical catalytic systems. In this section, we aim to summarize the recent process on the utilization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials as electrocatalysts in a number of important electrocatalytic reactions, including HER, oxygen evolution reaction (OER), ORR, and carbon dioxide reduction. 6.2.1. Hydrogen Evolution Reaction (HER). Searching for an efficient electrocatalyst toward HER with low overpotential as well as being earth-abundant and inexpensive to replace the prevailing Pt-based catalysts holds great promise for clean and sustainable energy. HER reaction involves the process of protons from the solution combining with the electrons at the electrode to form hydrogen gas. Density function theory (DFT) calculations have shown that a good catalyst for HER should meet a criterion; that is, the Gibbs free energy of atomic hydrogen adsorbed on the catalyst (ΔGH) should be close to zero.760 Inspired by the active sites of the nitrogenase enzymes in nature, the 2H-MoS2 nanoparticle is predicted as a promising active electrocatalyst for HER as its ΔGH is only +0.08 eV for the Mo-terminated zigzag edge of MoS2.
760 Further experimental research by Chorkendorff and co-workers established a direct correlation between the MoS2 density islanding on Au(111) and the HER activity.638 The linear dependence of the exchange current density with the MoS2 edge length and independent of the MoS2 area coverage reveals the edge, rather than the basal plane, as the active site for HER (Figure 36a− c).638 With the rapid progress achieved on the preparation of ultrathin 2D TMD nanomaterials,761,762 MoS2 and its analogues have been widely investigated as HER catalysts in acid media. As compared to its bulk counterparts, ultrathin 2D TMD nanomaterials are better electrocatalysts for HER, benefiting from high surface-to-volume ratio and unique thickness-dependent electronic structures.763 Yu et al. reported that the catalytic activity of the 2H-MoS2 decreases by a factor of ∼4.47 for every additional layer (Figure 36d−f).764 This thickness-dependent HER activity was also observed for the MoS2 nanoparticle; that is, the turnover frequency of the MoS2 nanoparticle is in a quasi-linear manner with decreased number of layers.765 Gao et al. reported the expanded MoS2 nanosheet with interlayer spacing ∼9.4 Å that enables the electronic structure to approach its monolayer equivalent (Figure 36g).766 Furthermore, the DFT calculation shows that the hydrogen absorption energy (ΔEH) on Mo edges decreases by about 0.05 eV for expanded MoS2 nanosheets as compared to that of the nonexpanded one (Figure 36h). The reduced ΔEH of the expanded MoS2 enables fast proton absorption kinetics on the
Mo edge. The advantages of the abundance of the active edge sites, and the enlarged interlayer distance with modified edge electronic structures, result in the high performance of this MoS2 catalyst (Figure 36i). These results emphasize the benefit and importance of utilization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials as electrocatalysts for HER. Catalytic activity is a highly important parameter in evaluating the efficacy of any catalysts. With regard to HER catalysts, the activity is determined by two factors: the number of active sites and the intrinsic activity (turnover frequency) of each site.767 To design HER catalysts with better performance, catalysts need to be designed with high density of active sites and high intrinsic activity of the active sites. Considering that the edge sites of pristine TMD nanomaterials act as active sites for HER, the direct strategy to enhance its activity is by increasing the exposure to the edge sites as high as possible. Bearing this in mind, reducing the size of ultrathin 2D TMD catalysts to increase the number of active sites per unit volume is an effective way to enhance their activities.768−771 Mesoporous MoS2 nanofilm with preferentially exposed active edge sites shows excellent activity for HER originating from the high surface and large fraction of edges sites.768 Yang et al. reported that single crystalline MoS2 nanobelt with the top surface fully covered by edge sites shows low onset potential for HER than that of single-layer MoS2.
769 To obtain single-layer MoS2 with increasing edge sites, a dendritic MoS2 nanosheet was synthesized on the lattice-mismatch SrTiO3(001) substrate via a low-pressure CVD method.772 The dendritic MoS2 nanosheet can be easily transferred on conductive Au foil electrode and served as the electrocatalyst for HER, which presents a low Tafel slope of ∼73 mV/dec among CVD-grown MoS2 nanosheets. 772
Because the resistivity measured through the basal planes of MoS2 is 2200 times larger than the value parallel to the planes,773 the ideal structure of 2D TMD-based nanosheets for HER should be one that is vertically grown on the substrate. Such structure can simultaneously fulfill the high density exposure of active sites while decreasing the resistive losses from the electron transport. Cui and co-workers presented a facile way to grow vertically aligned crystalline MoS2 or MoSe2 films on planar substrate with maximally exposing edge sites on the film surface.774 The obtained films are ideal for HER, showing high exchange current density but quite high Tafel slope in the range of 105−120 mV/dec.774 This method has been extended to obtain vertically aligned MoSe2 and WSe2 films on curved conductive substrates, which demonstrate enhanced performance for HER as compared to that on the planar substrate.775
With regard to ultrathin 2D TMD nanosheets, the geometry creates a tendency to restack on top of each other, which may create some problems: First, the active edges sites may be partially embedded, causing the loss of activity. Second, restacking hampers the electron transfer process. Therefore, maintaining the 2D TMD nanomaterials dispersion during electrode fabrication for HER is a critical issue. One facile way to solve the problem is to use conductive supports to improve the dispersion of 2D nanomaterials. At the same time, the conductive support can also enhance the conductivity, which will increase the activity of the catalyst.776−778 Chen et al. reported the preparation of a MoO3@MoS2 core/shell nanowire array on the substrate by the sulfurization of the asprepared MoO3 nanorod. In this work, the MoO3 nanowire served as a conductive core, and the coated MoS2 nanosheet

6263
served as HER catalyst.779 Furthermore, decorating 2D TMD nanosheets with metal nanoparticles, such as Au, Pd, and Pt, can physically inhibit the restacking of nanosheets and improve the charge transfer and mass transport, enhancing their activities.139,780
Besides increasing the numbers of the edge sites per unit volume, increasing the overall turnover frequency is another effective way to improve the activity of ultrathin TMD nanosheets for HER. Several approaches have been used to pursue this aim, including introducing defects and/or strain to activate additional sites, doping 2D TMDs with heteroatoms to tune its electronic structure, and phase engineering of TMDs (e.g., 1T phase).
Defects commonly exist in 2D TMD nanomaterials (natural MoS2 and monolayer MoS2 prepared by exfoliation and CVD methods) and usually play an important role in tailoring their electric as well as optical properties.109,781,782 These defects have different electronic structures, so introducing defects may bring additional active sites for HER. Xie et al. reported the preparation of the defects-rich MoS2 nanosheet.
205 Lots of dislocations and distortion can be found on the nanosheet from the HRTEM images, and the (001) planes of the MoS2 rotate slightly from each other. The resulting defect-rich nanosheet shows enhanced HER performance as compared to pure MoS2 with the onset potential of 120 mV.205 The basal planes of 2HMoS2 are inert for HER, but their surface area is much larger that of the active edge sites for ultrathin 2D nanosheets.

Activating the basal planes of MoS2 for HER will greatly enhance its activity. Lee et al. reported that the HER activity of the chemically exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet could be enhanced when mechanical tensile strain is applied on it.783 The tensilestrain induced MoS2 nanosheet showed significantly steeper polarization curves and lower Tafel slope than the strain-free one.783 Other uncontrollable factors, such as the amount change of exposed edge sites with the applied strain, cannot be completely excluded in their experimental design. Tan et al. synthesized monolayer MoS2 on the surface of a porous gold substrate via the CVD method.784 The binding angles of S− Mo−S of the monolayer MoS2 under annular bright-field STEM image showed an obvious variation on curved gold substrate, indicating that the monolayer MoS2 experienced serious out-of-plane strains on the curved nanoporous gold substrate. Meanwhile, the monolayer MoS2 was found lacking of uncoordinated steps and lattice defects. These characteristics reflected that it was an ideal system to study the catalytic properties of the monolayer MoS2 with the lattice stain. The HER test showed that the strained monolayer of MoS2 on nanoporous gold had a lower onset overpotential (118 mV) and Tafel slope (46 mV/dec),784 as compared to the flat MoS2 nanosheet764 and vertically grown MoS2 film.
774 Li et al. reported a new approach to activate the basal plane of the monolayer MoS2 by introducing S vacancies and strain, in which the strain was formed through capillary force between the MoS2 film and patterned gold nanocone support and the S vacancies were introduced by the argon plasma treatment (Figure 37a).207 The aberration-corrected STEM image confirmed that S vacancies were successfully introduced by argon plasma treatment, and the amount of S vacancies could be easily controlled by tuning the argon plasma treatment time (Figure 37b).207 To investigate individual as well as collective effects of strain and S-vacancies on the catalytic HER activity of monolayer 2H-MoS2, as-transferred MoS2 (strain 0% and Svacancy 0%), strained MoS2 without S-vacancy (S-MoS2), unstrained MoS2 with S-vacancy (V-MoS2), and strained MoS2 with S-vacancy (SV-MoS2), as well as Au substrate and Pt electrode have been tested. It can be seen from the linear sweep voltammograms (LSV) (Figure 37c) that the as-transferred MoS2 (MoS2) has very low HER activity because the main basal plane is inert for HER. Strain alone (S-MoS2) only slightly increases the HER activity, whereas the S-vacancy alone (VMoS2) significantly increases the HER activity. Impressively, the combination of strain and S vacancies (SV-MoS2) leads to even higher HER activity. The corresponding Tafel plots (Figure 37d) show that the strain decreases the Tafel slope from 98 to 90 mV/dec, whereas the S-vacancies reduce the Tafel slope to 82 mV/dec. In contrast, combining strain and Svacancies decreases the Tafel slope to 60 mV/dec.207 It should be noted that the turnover frequency per S-vacancy site of SVMoS2 at 0 V versus RHE is 0.08−0.31 s−1, which is better than the vertically grown MoS2 film. 774
Doping transition metals, such as Fe, Co, and Ni, into 2D TMD nanomaterials can significantly alter the chemical bonding states, thereby increasing HER activity.785,786 The STM studies performed by Kibsgaard et al. revealed that the dopants were predominantly located at the S-edges of the MoS2 nanoclusters, which modify the hydrogen binding energy.787 DFT calculation showed that the hydrogen binding energy, ΔGH, at the S-edge of the Co-incorporated MoS2 decreased from 0.18 eV for unmodified MoS2 to 0.10 eV, while the ΔGH at the Mo-edge was unaffected at 0.08 eV.786 Therefore, the
role of incorporated atoms is to boost the activity of nanostructured MoS2 catalysts by activating the S-edges. It is still an open question if we can further decrease the hydrogen binging energy approach to zero by doping strategies. Besides incorporating dopants at the S-edges, in-plane doping to form mixed 2D TMDs is another promising way to achieve higher activity for HER. The intralayer vanadiumdoped MoS2 showed semimetal property as compared to the pristine semiconductor MoS2.
788 Benefiting from the enhanced electronic conductivity and the improved carrier concentration, the vanadium-doped MoS2 showed improved activity for HER with the onset overpotential at 130 mV. Considering that the stable intrinsically metallic or semimetallic ultrathin TMD nanosheets are the optimal choice of catalysts for HER, further efforts are still needed to elucidate how the doping affected the property of 2D TMDs to additionally enhance its performance. Besides the transition metal doping, the anionic atom doping can also enhance HER activity of 2D TMD nanosheets. Xu et al. found that the S-doped MoSe2 nanosheet showed a lower onset overpotential of 90 mV and Tafel slope of 58 mV/dec. They attributed the improved catalytic effects to the proliferation of unsaturated HER active sites in MoSe2 resulting from S-doping.789 Xie et al. reported that oxygen incorporation into disordered MoS2 nanosheet effectively tailored its electronic structure by reducing the bandgap and increasing the intrinsic conductivity, hence leading to the enhancement of HER activity.532 It is well-known that the design of alloyed TMDs can continuously tune their compositions and band gaps,500,503,511,790 which also provides the possibility to engineer hydrogen binding energy and therefore improve HER performance. The monolayer MoS2(1−x)Se2x nanosheets have shown better HER performances such as lower overpotential reduction and slope, as compared to monolayer MoS2 and MoSe2.
791 Alloy of MoS2(1−x)Se2x nanoflakes showed even better activity for HER with small overpotentials in the range of 80−100 mV and Tafel slopes in the range of 45−55 mV/dec, close to the theoretical value of 40 mV/dec when the Volmer− Heyrovsky reaction pathway is the rate-limiting step.792,793 The enhanced activity of alloyed MoS2(1−x)Se2x nanosheets can be attributed to the continuous tailoring of the hydrogen binding energy. Earlier theoretical calculation demonstrated that hydrogen adsorption is slightly too weak on sulfided Mo edges (ΔGH = 80 meV) but slightly too strong on selenide Mo edges (ΔGH = −140 meV).762,794 By optimizing the ratio of S and Se, the hydrogen binding energy can be tuned close to zero, thus maximizing HER activity. A similar situation can be also observed on alloyed WS2(1−x)Se2x nanosheets, which show enhanced activity as compared to pure WS2 and WSe2.
509,795 Fu et al. reported that the monolayer MoS2(1−x)Se2x with x value at 0.43 has shown the best HER activity with overpotential of 80 mV and a Tafel slope of 85 mV/dec among monolayer MoS2(1−x)Se2x with different S/Se ratios. 509
Phase engineering of TMD nanomaterials is another fascinating strategy for the development of 2D TMD-based HER catalysts with high catalytic activities. Theoretical calculations on monolayer MoS2 have indicated that the 1T′ and 2H phases are stable under normal conditions, while the 1T phase is unstable and cannot be realized.796 Meanwhile, it has been predicted that the 1T′ phase is the most active polytype because both of its basal planes and edge sites are active sites for HER, while the basal planes of the 1H and 1T polytypes are HER inactive and their edge-sites are not as active as those of the 1T′ polytype.797 On the basis of the

experimental results, the 1T′ phase was found to be the least stable and to relax into the 2H phase in a multistep process, through metastable 1T phase intermediate, when induced by mild heating.660,798,799 Phase transformation of TMD nanosheets has been induced and monitored in real time using TEM, and it is possible to reversibly tune the stable 2H and metastable 1T phase under appropriate irradiation conditions.108 Providing additional electrons is required for phase transformation from the 2H to the 1T phase, and a facile way for tuning the phase of TMDs under normal condition is based on the intercalation of alkali metals (e.g., Li). A detailed study has been performed by Wang et al. to tailor the multiple important properties of TMDs by controlling the amount of the intercalated Li, including tuning the oxidation state of Mo, the transition of semiconducting 2H phase to metallic 1T phase, and expanding the van der Waals gap until exfoliation.800 Li intercalation has at least three effects on the electronic structure of MoS2, that is, increasing the layer spacing to change the band structure, reducing the oxidation state of Mo by changing the d-band filling, and inducing a phase transition from the semiconducting 2H phase to the metallic 1T phase.800 Because of its metallic nature, 1T-phase MoS2 nanosheets have demonstrated higher HER activity than 2H counterparts, which can be attributed to the facile electrode kinetics, low-loss electrical transport, and high density of catalytic active sites.117,801 In the case by Voiry et al., they claimed that the origin of main active sites on the 1T-phase MoS2 nanosheet was from the basal planes, rather than the edges.117 The conclusion was drawn on the basis of the investigation of the activity of partially oxidized 2H-phase MoS2 and 1T-phase MoS2 nanosheets. It showed that the activity of 2H-phase MoS2 was significantly reduced after oxidation, presumably due to the oxidation of the edge sites, while the 1T-phase MoS2 remains unaffected after oxidation (Figure 37e−h).117 Loading the Liintercalated 1T-MoS2 nanoparticles on carbon fiber paper with high surface area further boosts HER performance with exchange current density of 200 mA/cm2 at only 200 mV overpotential.802 The metallic 1T-WS2 nanosheet also facilitates the hydrogen evolution with very low overpotentials.803,804 Voiry et al. have found that a high concentration of strain is responsible for the enhanced HER activity. High-resolution STEM image confirmed the existence of a distorted 1T phase (like 1T′ phase). The calculation demonstrates that the free energy of the hydrogen adsorption decreases from 0.28 eV, without strain, to 0 eV, when the strain reaches 2.7%.803
The activity of the basal planes of the 1T′ MoS2 has been confirmed by the combination of aberration-corrected STEM and density functional theory.805 Chou et al. found that complete transformation of MoS2 from 2H to 1T′ phase can be achieved through prolonging the Li interaction time to 240 h and the dye-sensitized HER activity of the exfoliated MoS2 scales proportionately with the 1T′ signature. The calculation demonstrated that the hydrogen adsorption energy on the basal plane decreases from +1.6 eV for 2H to +0.18 eV for 1T′MoS2. DFT shows the stability of the 1T′ surpasses 2H when H coverage is larger than 0.4.805 The exfoliated metallic TMD nanosheets are rich in electrons; hence, the stability of these nanosheets is attributed to the presence of protons or other immobile, positively charged ions on the nanosheet surface. This is also the reason that the 1T phase relaxes to the 2H phase upon mild annealing due to desorption of the impurities. Voiry et al. further reported that the electron-rich property of the 1T phase enables them to do covalent functionalization of
organic groups by electron transfer between the metallic 1T phase and an organoiodine reactant.806 The functionalization process accompanies the phase change of monolayer MoS2 from the 1T to 2H phase. This finding points out the challenge to stabilize the metastable phase and the possibility to design chemical modification of ultrathin 2D TMD nanosheets. The hot electron generated by plasmonic gold nanostructures has also claimed to induce a reversible 2H to 1T phase transformation in monolayer MoS2, promoting its HER activity.807−809 Furthermore, the strain and strain engineering are theoretically predicted as important variables in phase transformation of monolayer TMD nanosheets.810 Although various strategies have shown the ability to reversibly engineer the phase of TMD materials, it is still critical to comprehensively analyze the correlation of HER performance with phases, elucidate the catalytic mechanism, and find a way to stabilize the active metastable phases. The wet-chemical synthesis method has also been used for synthesizing the active-phased 2D TMD nanomaterials. Mahler et al. have synthesized 1T- and 2H-WS2 nanosheets by adjusting the synthetic process.586 The obtained 1T-WS2 nanosheet is monodispersed with a diameter of about 100 nm, whereas the 2H-WS2 nanosheet is aggregated with a flower-like structure. Pure and stable metallic phase MoS2 nanosheet has been successfully prepared, and it exhibits superior activity for HER with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low potential of −175 mV and Tafel slope of 41 mV/ dec.811
In addition to layered TMDs, the family of pyrite phase of transition metal dichalcogenides (MX2, M = Fe, Co, or Ni, and X = S or Se) has also been identified as promising HER catalysts. A systematical study on the HER performance of thin films of this family was performed by Cui, Jin, and co-workers, and they revealed that this family of materials shows relatively fast kinetics to drive HER in acid media.812,813 Note that the CoS2, CoSe2, and NiS2 possess the smallest Tafel slopes near 40 mV/dec as compared to others. Making the thin CoSe2 shell on the carbon nanoparticles further dramatically improves the activity with lower onset overpotential as compared to CoSe2 film.812 Following this finding, a variety of nanostructured pyrite phase metal dichalcogenides, for example, CoS2 814,815 and CoSe2, 816−818 have been prepared. In these reports, the smallest Tafel slope with a value of 31.2 mV/dec, which is close to the Pt/C catalyst, has been achieved on the polymorphic CoSe2. DFT calculation revealed that the kinetics energy barrier of H atom adsorption on FeS2 surface reduces to a large extent when the Co is doped in the pyrite FeS2.
819 The corresponding experimental result verified that the Fe0.9Co0.1S2 nanosheet hybridized with CNTs has the best performance for HER.819 Jin and co-workers reported a new ternary pyrite type cobalt phosphosulfide (CoPS) as a high performance catalyst for HER, with a geometrical catalytic current density of 10 mA cm−2 at overpotentials as low as 48 mV.820 Furthermore, Wu et al. reported a templated method for the preparation of vertically grown NiS2 nanosheet on the graphite support, and the obtained NiS2 electrocatalyst shows excellent activity and stability toward HER in acidic media, with overpotential of −110 mV and low Tafel slope of ∼40 mV/dec.821 The composite synthesized by in situ growth of MoS2 nanosheet on CoSe2 nanobelt shows fast hydrogen evolution kinetics with onset potential of only −11 mV and Tafel slope of 36 mV/ dec.822 The authors ascribe the enhanced activity to the

synergistic effect between the active MoS2 and CoSe2 and increased catalytic sites. Doped graphene sheets have also been studied as promising catalysts for HER. The intermolecular doping of graphene with heteroatoms can effectively tailor its electronic structure and chemical properties. Qiao and co-workers reported that N, P codoped graphene shows a much lower overpotential and high exchange current density than those of pure and single-doped graphene samples.823 They attributed the enhanced activity in codoped graphene to the synergistic coupling effect between the two heteroatoms as they could coactivate the adjacent carbon atom in the graphene by tuning its valence orbital energy levels and leading to a reduced ΔGH, which was predicted by DFT calculation.823 They also prepared a hybrid nanomaterial by chemical coupling of g-C3N4 with nitrogendoped graphene, and the hybrid exhibited an unexpected favorable HER activity, comparable to some of the state-of-theart metallic materials.824 DFT calculation has showed that chemical coupling of g-C3N4 and N-graphene into a uniform hybrid results in a mediated adsorption−desorption behavior (as the ΔGH values are opposite in signs), which facilitates the overall HER kinetics.824 This finding points out the potential strategies for the design of metal-free hybrid materials with high HER performance. 6.2.2. Oxygen Evolution Reaction (OER). In water splitting, the oxidative half reaction (OER) is often kinetically sluggish and leads to large kinetic overpotential loss.825,826 The commonly used highly efficient OER catalysts, such as IrO2 and RuO2, are earth-low abundance and expensive, which inhibit their practical applications. Therefore, developing low-cost and earth-abundant OER electrocatalysts with high efficiency attracts extensive attention.827 In the last few decades, earthabundant TMOs/transition metal (oxy)hydroxides have been widely investigated as OER catalysts in alkaline media, and the correlation between the intrinsic activities with the local
structures and compositions has been established.828 LDHs become prevailing alternatives as OER catalysts.829 In fact, Fe, Co, or Ni-based LDHs have shown promising activities for OER in alkaline media.141,142,830 For instance, Zou et al. reported the bimetallic Zn−Co LDH nanosheet serving as an efficient OER electrocatalyst, exhibiting low overpotential and higher TOF than that of monometallic Co-based LDHs.830 Song et al. reported that the Co−Mn LDH showed high OER efficiency, and its TOF was about 9 times higher than that of the precious IrO2 catalyst.
141 Although the transition metalbased LDHs have shown the potential capability for OER, their performances should be further optimized so it can couple better with HER. There are two main drawbacks limiting the performance of LDHs for OER: the poor electronic conductivity and limited active sites. To overcome the low electrical conductivity and increase the charge transfer, LDH nanosheets are commonly grown directly on different kinds of conductive supports, especially a variety of carbon nanomaterials, such as graphene, multiwalled CNTs (MWCNTs), rGO, and 3D graphene.831−836 The growth of LDH nanosheets on conductive carbon materials can effectively enhance their OER activities by improving the electrical conductivity and creating additional channels for chemical transfer. For instance, Long et al. reported that the overpotential of the strong coupled graphene and Fe−Ni LDH hybrid could be reduced to as low as 200 mV and the TOF could reach up to 1 S−1 under the overpotential of 0.3 V.832 The synergistic effect between the conductive carbon and LDH could alter the oxidation state of the transition metal in the LDH and further increase its performance as the active species. A higher oxidation state of Ni species in Ni(OH)2/MWCNT composite, than that of physically mixed, has been confirmed by XPS, which could be the reason for the explanation of the lower onset potential observed in the composites for OER.833 The finding of the synergistic effect between LDHs and carbon materials maps out

a promising strategy for further improving its activities by using various doped carbon materials. Another way to enhance the electrical conductivity of LDHs is to directly grow LDH nanosheets on 3D conductive substrates. This method is also a potential way to fulfill the practical application of LDHs as the anodes for water oxidation. Until now, the nickel foam has been widely chosen as the 3D conductive substrate as it is commercially available. For instance, Lu and Zhao used an electrodeposition method for growth of amorphous mesoporous Ni−Fe composite on the nickel foam, and the obtained composite electrode exhibited high activity for OER in alkaline media with low overpotential of 200 mV.837 Remarkably, the electrode could deliver a high current density of 500 mA cm−2 at an overpotential of only 240 mV, satisfying the requirements for commercial water electrolyzer.837 To further increase the loading amount of active LDH nanosheets, the hierarchical structure based on the nanowire array on the nickel foam was also used for growth of NiCoFe LDH nanoplates, and the obtained hierarchical electrode exhibited an efficient and stable catalytic activity for OER with a Tafel slope of 53 mV/dec.838
LDHs are a class of ionic layered compounds consisting of intercalated balanced anions and solvation molecules within the positively brucite-like layers in LDHs, and these anions can be simply exchanged, so the interlayer distance of LDHs can be easily tuned by choosing different anions with various ionic diameters.24 In fact, the OER activity of LDHs has been proven to correlate with the interlayer spacing, that is, the larger interlayer spacing, the higher activity, where the increased activity could be attributed to the more exposed active sites and better exchange ability of the reactive anion (OH−) in the interlamination.839 The exfoliation of LDHs down to several layers or even to monolayer is an ideal way to further increase their active sites. Song and Hu reported that single-layer LDH nanosheet showed an enhanced OER activity higher than that of the bulk counterpart and even better than the performance of IrO2 in alkaline solution.
141 The exfoliated single-layer NiFe LDH nanosheet exhibited higher activity than CoCo and NiCo LDHs with a Tafel slope of 40 mV/dec and TOF of 0.05 S−1 (Figure 38a−d).141 In their report, the oxidative agent, bromine or iodine, was used to oxidize Co2+ (Fe2+) in transition-metal double hydroxides into Co3+ (Fe3+), producing the Br2−- or I− (I3 −)-intercalated LDHs, which were then exfoliated into charged nanosheets.70,840 An extra oxidation step is sometimes required to oxidize the Co2+ to Co3+ in preparation process because hydrated Co3+ ions are more active in OER than are the Co2+ ions. To overcome the tedious synthesis process, Jin and co-workers reported the direct preparation of Ni−Co LDH, in which ammonia was used to oxidize initially formed [Co(NH3)6] 2+ to [Co(NH3)6] 3+.841 The as-prepared LDH crystal was then exfoliated into LDH nanosheets, which also showed good activity for water oxidation. Decreasing the thickness of LDHs can greatly increase their electrical surface area (ECSA). The enhancement of catalytic activities of exfoliated LDH nanosheets for OER was often found to be even larger than the increment of the ESCA as compared to asprepared bulk LDHs.141,841 The much enhanced OER catalytic activities may have originated from the unique chemical and electronic properties of exfoliated LDH nanosheets or the more exposed edge sites and defects formed after exfoliation. Besides LDHs, transition-metal double hydroxides and oxy(hydroxide)s have also been widely investigated as OER catalysts.842−844 Similar to LDHs, the composition and
morphology of double hydroxides also greatly affect the intrinsic activities of these compounds. For instance, it has been demonstrated that NiFe, NiCr, and NiMn double hydroxides have superior catalytic activities among those transition metal-doped Ni(OH)2 catalysts for OER. The active centers in NiFe and NiMn double hydroxides are Fe and Mn, while Ni is the active center in NiCr double oxides.842 Wang et al. reported that the single-layer NixCo1−x(OH)2 showed superior activity over the multilayer counterparts.845 Wang and co-workers reported the synthesis of a unique spiral structured bimetallic hydroxide nanosheet spiral structure, which demonstrated excellent activity for OER with the overpotential as low as ∼210 mV.846 Furthermore, spinel-structured oxides are also efficient catalysts for OER.847 As the OER catalytic activities of spinelstructured oxides are strongly correlated with the available active surface and defects, porous nanoplate structure is a morphologically good candidate for the water oxidation. It possesses large surface area and increases the probability of charge transfer by reducing the grain boundaries.848,849 Xie and co-workers reported that the NiCo2O4 nanosheet rich in oxygen vacancies demonstrated a superior activity for OER with an overpotential of 320 mV and a Tafel slope of 30 mV/ dec.850 The DFT calculation showed that the oxygen vacancies confined in ultrathin nanosheets could lower the adsorption energy of H2O, leading to an increased OER efficiency. Although many OER catalysts are being developed, little is known about the active species during the oxidation process. Several active species have been proposed on the basis of theoretical calculations,851,852 but it is still necessary to uncover the relation between intrinsic activity, structure, and catalyst composition for exploring a better OER electrocatalysis candidate. It has been experimentally demonstrated that amorphous structures show remarkably enhanced activity as compared to their crystalline counterparts.141,853 During the harsh OER process, the structure and surface chemical state of the catalyst might vary with the applied potential. An in situ grazing angle X-ray diffraction method has been used to identify the correlation between the oxygen evolution under applied potential and the formation of the active species.854 Metal oxyhydroxide was revealed as the active phase for OER as it formed under high applied voltage, consistent with the theoretical calculation.852 Note that the exposed surface also has an effect on the intrinsic activity of the electrocatalyst as it determines the adsorption energies of the intermediates on the surface.855 The deep understanding of the structure-dependent activity of the electrocatalyst can in return guide us to rationally design and synthesize ultrathin 2D nanosheets for highly efficient OER catalysts. Element doping is a common strategy to enhance the catalytic activity of OER catalysts. It also raises the difficulties to identify the active species during the oxidation process. The experimental investigation has demonstrated that Ni(OH)2 film aged in unpurified KOH solution can incorporate a large amount of Fe; hence, the catalytic activity of the film greatly increases, as compared to the Ni(OH)2 film aged in the Fe-free solution.856 It should be noted that the Fe incorporation can proceed under very low Fe concentration (<1 ppm Fe). A similar study also showed that contamination of nickel impurity in the electrolyte is enough to act as efficient catalyst on substrates for OER in alkaline solution.857 These findings raise the burden of verifying the active species in OER, and, additionally, stricter control experiments should be performed

to exclude the possibility of contamination contributing to catalytic activities of OER catalysts. 2D chalcogenides (sulfides and selenides) are also investigated as alternative OER catalysts.858−864 For instance, Xie and co-workers reported that ZrS3 and Co3S4 nanosheets showed good activity for water oxidation.860,861 Especially, a selective exposure surface with octahedral-coordination cations can engineer the spin states of the Co3+. Hence, Co3S4 nanosheet manifests with an OER onset potential as low as 310 mV under neutral conditions, benefiting from the atomic structural and electronic configuration modulations.861 Furthermore, they also demonstrated the CoSe2 nanosheet as a promising water oxidation electrocatalyst due to its metallic characteristics, allowing for fast electron transfer.862,863 Introducing cobalt vacancies in the CoSe2 nanosheet provides much more active sites for OER, manifesting with OER overpotential as low as 0.32 V at 10 mA cm−2 in pH 13 medium.863 Although these transition metal chalcogenides demonstrate quite good activity for OER, its mechanistic activity still needs further investigation as these sulfide and selenides are easy to oxidize under the harsh oxidation process. Transition metal nitrides are another kind of promising material for OER because of their metallic properties, which can improve the electrical conductivity and decrease the internal potential loss. Xu et al. reported that the Ni3N nanosheet with thickness ∼3 nm exhibited an excellent OER activity with a small Tafel slope of 45 mV/dec in O2-saturated and basic solution (1 M KOH). The OER performance was further improved by coupling it with a carbon cloth, realizing a high catalytic current density of 52.3 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 350 mV.865 In a similar OER study by Shalom et al., the Ni3N layer was coated on a nickel foam. They attributed the high catalytic activity of Ni3N to the formation of a Ni(OH)2 surface layer during the electrochemical reaction, which was confirmed by the XPS.866 The finding highlighted again that detailed characterization of the catalysts’ compositions and chemical states after OER is critical as it helps to reveal the active species during the OER process. Doped graphitic carbon nanomaterials have also become a kind of attractive and promising catalyst for OER in recent years because of their low-cost and facile scale-up preparation.867−869 Some problems still persist, such as low activity for OER and the poor stability under high applied voltage. Therefore, further explorations are still needed to fulfill their potential application in zinc-O2 batteries. 6.2.3. Oxygen Reduction Reaction (ORR). The ORR plays an important role in fuel cells and metal-air batteries.870−872 Developing efficient and low-cost electrocatalysts to replace precious and nondurable Pt-based catalysts for the sluggish ORR is a key issue for implanting these energy systems in practical applications. In aqueous solution, the ORR is a multistep reaction process proceeded mainly by two pathways: (1) the 4-electron reduction of oxygen to H2O (in acid electrolytes) or OH − (in base electrolytes), and (2) the 2-electron reduction of oxygen to H2O2 (in acid electrolytes) or HO2
− (in base electrolytes) as intermediates. Pt-based materials display excellent activities for ORR, but the high cost and poor durability preclude their wide application.873 With the development and achievement on the high-performance M−N−C (M = Fe and/or Co)874,875 and N-doped carbon nanotube array catalysts,876 great research efforts have been made in developing nonprecious metal catalysts and metal-free carbon-based
catalysts for replacing expensive noble metal catalysts. With the prevailing of 2D nanomaterials, graphene sheets doped with heteroatoms have been demonstrated to be promising catalysts for ORR.203,877 The heteroatom doping in graphene can effectively modulate its electronic and chemical properties, creating charged sites favorable for oxygen adsorption. Meanwhile, the rich π electrons of graphene are utilized for oxygen reduction.878 Until now, a variety of methods have been developed for the synthesis of graphene sheets doped/codoped with various heteroatoms, such as N, B, P, S, Cl, Br, and I, and corresponding studies have been reviewed previously.203,871 Given that, we mainly focus on the introduction of the utilization of heteroatom-doped graphene sheets for electrocatalytic ORR in this section. When heteroatoms are doped into the graphene, the originally electroneutral graphene is broken to create active sites for ORR, as heteroatoms have different electronegativity values as compared to the carbon atom. Sometimes, the induced strain and stress can be formed if larger sized heteroatoms are incorporated into the graphene, changing the charge distribution and eventually facilitating the catalytic process.878 The doping configurations and levels depend on the synthesis routes, which are important for the catalytic activity of the doped graphene. Taking the N-doped graphene as a typical example, nitrogen atoms can be incorporated into the graphene basal planes in several configurations: pyrrolic-, pyridinic-, and graphitic-N, all distinguishable by the XPS.879 These types of N-species commonly coexisted in N-doped graphene independent of the synthetic method. The doping level of the nitrogen and relative atomic ratio of N-species in graphene are controlled by tuning the synthetic conditions. The doped N-species in graphene are considered as the origins of their ORR activities because they can effectively tune the electronic structure of neighboring carbon atoms and then affect their physical and chemical properties.880 The actual ORR active N-species remains elusive and is still a matter of controversy. Either pyridinic-N135,881−883 or graphitic-N868,884 in N-doped graphene has been proposed as the active sites for ORR. In some cases, pyrrolic-N was proven to correlate with the ORR activity of the N-doped graphene.885 Ruoff and coworkers investigated the active sites of N-doped graphene by different post-thermal annealing methods. They found that the electrocatalytic activity of N-doped graphene is relevant to the graphitic-N content, while the pyridinic-N content could improve the onset potential for ORR.886 In fact, it is hard to recognize the contribution from a specific N-species to the ORR process. The observed ORR activity is just a collective properties; unless a particular N-species doped graphene can be exclusively synthesized, then its actual activity can be measured. One possible approach is synthetic organic chemistry, which provides a controlled design and way to synthesize specific Ndoped nanographene.887−889 Atomically precise preparation of doped graphene has not been achieved thus far yet. A model catalyst on highly oriented pyrolytic graphite (HOPG) with well-controlled doping of pyridinic-N or graphitic-N has been fabricated to determine the active sites for ORR (Figure 39a,b). It shows that the ORR active sites are created by the pyridinic N, and the active sites are the carbon atoms with Lewis basicity next to pyridinic N that facilitate the initial oxygen adsorption step.890
Boron, which only has one less valence electron than carbon, is also an interesting candidate for doping carbon nanomaterials. Theoretical calculation has demonstrated that the B atom
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6269
can form sp2 hybridization in carbon lattices while keeping the planar structure of the graphene.891 The low electronegativity of the boron (2.04), as compared to that of carbon (2.55), can induce the charge redistribution and shift the Fermi level in band structure because boron can accept the electron from carbon, which can facilitate the ORR process. A previous study on ORR activity of B-doped CNTs has revealed the importance of the B-moieties in CNTs as proportional; that is, a higher B doping level causes higher ORR activity.892 The calculation performed by the authors has elucidated the possible reasons for the increasing ORR activity by B-doping as followed. Positively charged boron induces the chemisorption of the oxygen; then some π* electrons in the conjugated system accumulated on the boron dopants and act as electron donors to the chemisorbed oxygen for the ORR.892 The above electronic tuning can be applied for B-doped graphene. For instance, Sheng et al. reported a post-thermal annealing method for the synthesis of B-doped graphene, which showed excellent ORR activity with long-term stability under alkaline conditions and remarkable tolerances to methanol and CO.893 Large surface-area porous B-doped graphene has been prepared, and it also exhibited good performance for ORR.894
As compared to individually N- or B-doped carbon, the codoping of the two elements, which have different electronegativity values as compared to that of carbon, could lead to a unique electronic structure of carbon by the synergistic coupling effect between two heteroatoms.895 The ORR activity of the B,N-codoped carbon, according to the theoretical
calculation, is highly sensitive to the arrangement of these two moieties within the carbon backbones.896 The direct bond of B and N seems unfavorable for activating ORR, proven by the experiment on the B,N-codoped CNTs.897 The ORR performance test indicated that the bonded case can hardly break the inertness of CNTs, while the separated one can turn CNTs into an excellent ORR catalyst.897 The result highlights the importance of microstructure doping on the ORR performance, which can also be observed in codoped graphene. Dai and coworkers reported a post-treatment method for the synthesis of B,N-codoped graphene by thermally annealing GO with the boric acid under ammonia-rich atmosphere.
