Three types of BCN graphene with different stoichiometries, including B7C87N6, B12C77N11, and B38C28N34, and properties were obtained.898 Of these, the B38C28N34 is not a good catalyst for ORR due to its low conductivity associated with the large BN cluster, but B12C77N11 shows activity comparable to that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst, has good stability, high ORR selectivity, and an electron transfer number of almost 4.898 It has been reported that large BN clusters are easily formed in B,N-codoped graphene by the CVD method.899 To prevent formation of the undesired BN clusters in codoped graphene, Zheng et al. reported a two-step method for preparation of B,N-codoped graphene via subsequent doping of the nitrogen and boron atoms.136 The obtained B,N-codoped graphene shows better ORR activity in an alkaline medium than their singly B- or N-doped counterpart.136 In a similar approach, a variety of B- and N-sources can be used for thermal treatment of GO to produce B,N-codoped graphene,900,901 proving to be a good ORR catalyst, even under acid conditions.900 Besides graphene nanosheets, Xue et al. reported that a 3D B,Ncodoped graphene network also shows a much higher electrocatalytic activity toward ORR than the singly B- or Ndoped counterpart.902 The well-developed codoped graphene sheets have proven themselves as a class of promising ORR catalysts. The ORR performance of these catalysts is significantly different case by case, relating to its synthetic conditions. Therefore, the rational and repeatable synthetic approaches are needed for realizing their potential applications, and detailed studies are also required for exploring the underlying mechanism for their activities. The doping of sulfur, which has a very close electronegativity to carbon (S 2.58 and C 2.55), into carbon nanomaterials can also enhance the ORR activity of the obtained catalysts. The sulfur moieties in the doped carbon existed as an elemental S atom, C−S−C, C−SOx−C, C−SH, etc.
903−905 These functionalities are quite similar to those of the O-doped carbon nanomaterials, such as GO. It is still not clear whether sulfur can substitute carbon atoms in the sp2 network because no experimental evidence exists thus far, although theoretical calculations indicate the substitution works.906,907 The study on the large-area S-doped graphene grown by CVD demonstrated that most S atoms form the linear domains with accompanying formation of defects in graphene.908 With regard to the largescale synthesis of S-doped graphene, a post-treatment method via thermal annealing has been adopted.903,905,909 For instance, Yang et al. have reported the synthesis of S-doped graphene by using benzyl disulfide as the S precursor (Figure 39c). Note that this method can be easily extended to prepare Se-doped graphene if diphenyl diselenide is employed as the precursor.903 The obtained S-doped graphene at high annealing temperature shows a similar onset potential and higher current density as compared to the commercial Pt/C catalyst under alkaline
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6270
conditions, while exhibiting a higher selectivity for oxygen reduction with the electron transfer numbers close to 4 (Figure 39d).903 By using a similar approach, Yang et al. reported the synthesis of S-doped graphene by using the GO-porous silica sheet as the starting material. The S doping is achieved by thermal annealing under H2S-rich atmosphere.
910 In this method, the usage of porous silica can effectively prevent the aggregation of graphene and facilitate the doping process by assisting the gas transport. The obtained S-doped graphene also shows good activity for ORR with good resistance against crossover effect by methanol.910 The edge-selectively sulfurized graphene nanoplatelet also can perform as a good ORR catalyst.904 The authors of this work found that the oxidization of the doped graphene can further improve its capability to surpass the commercial Pt/C catalyst. They attributed the origin of high ORR activity to the spin density increase.904 It should be noted that the exact role of the S on the ORR activity of doped graphene is still unclear, and further study is needed to reveal the correlation between the catalytic activity and the configuration of S moieties. The codoped S with other heteroatoms, for example, N, in graphene can further improve their activity for ORR.911−914 Xu et al. reported that the codoped graphene shows improved onset potential and higher current density as compared to that of individually N- or S-doped graphene.911 A similar result is presented by Qiao and co-workers on the mesoporous N,Scodoped graphene by the post-treatment method.912 The obtained mesoporous N,S-codoped graphene has proven to be a remarkable metal-free catalyst for ORR with the electron transfer number of up to 3.6.912 The DFT calculation revealed that a synergistic effect in codoped graphene results from the changes of charge and spin densities at different sites of dually doped graphene, which lead to more active sites than singly doped samples.912 Furthermore, the 3D N,S-co-doped graphene framework can also be used as an excellent catalyst for ORR under alkaline conditions.913
Up to now, the studies on ORR activity of P-doped graphene are still scarce. Although the P atom has the same valence electron number with the N, it is still unclear whether it can be substituted into the sp2 carbon lattice, considering its large size as compared to N. Liu et al. reported that the P-doped graphite layer is capable of working as a metal-free catalyst for ORR in alkaline medium.915 The XPS confirms that the P atom has been incorporated into graphene layers through formation of P−C and P−O bonding sites. The P-doped catalyst showed superior activity as compared to the nondoped reference, confirming the importance of the heteroatom doping. However, its performance is still lower than that of the commercial Pt/C catalyst, and the electron transfer number is only about 3, which may result from its lower surface area and active sites.915 The thermal annealing of GO and triphenylphosphine has been used to synthesize P-doped graphene, which was reported by Hou and co-workers.916 The obtained P-doped graphene shows outstanding ORR stability and tolerance to methanol crossover effect, as well as excellent selectivity with the electron transfer number larger than 3.916 Using an ionic liquid 1-butyl-3methlyimidazolium hexafluorophosphate as P precursor, Li et al. reported the post-thermal annealing method for the synthesis of P-doped graphene with large surface area and relatively high P-doping level (1.16 atom %). The P-doped graphene exhibits performance comparable to that of the commercial Pt/C under alkaline condition. The authors attributed the origin of the excellent activity to the partial
oxidization of P atom working as the active sites and the increase of open active sites during the P doping.917 Furthermore, it is found that the additional P doping in the N-doped carbon nanomaterials can improve their ORR activities under alkaline or acid conditions.900,918−920 For instance, Woo and co-workers reported that the N,P-doped graphene shows little improvement for ORR onset potential as compared to that of N-doped graphene, but the mass activity of N,P-doped graphene is 1.8 times higher than that of N-doped graphene at 0.75 V (vs RHE) in 0.1 M HClO4. 900
Halogens are very reactive, and they can transform the sp2 carbon bonding to the sp3 state. Among them, F element forms strong and inert bonding with carbon. So, as far as we know, no catalytic activity of the F-doped graphene has been reported. Alternatively, Jeon et al. reported the synthesis of a series of edge-halogenated graphene nanoplates (XGnPs, X = Cl, Br, or I) by a ball milling method and investigated their electrocatalytic performance toward ORR.921 The experimental ORR activity of XGnPs is in the order of ClGnP < BrGnP < IGnP, opposite to the electronegativity trend of halogen dopants, that is, Cl (3.16) > Br (2.96) > I (2.66). Considering the atomic size of halogen dopants, the authors suggested that Br and I elements can form partially ionized bonds of −Br+− and −I+− to enhance the charge transfer, which has been verified by the first-principle DFT calculation. The charge transfer weakens the O−O bond strength of the adsorbed oxygen with the most prominent case found in IGnP.921 Huang and co-workers reported that the I-doped graphene shows comparable onset potential but better current density than the commercial Pt/C catalyst. The XPS and Raman spectroscopy confirm the formation of I3
− in I-doped graphene, which is considered as the key factor for the enhancement of the ORR activity.922
Although great progress has been achieved in the usage of heteroatom doped-graphene sheets as metal-free catalysts, the mechanism underlying the dopant-induced ORR enhancement is still not completely clear. The main obstacle results from the lack of control of the configuration of the dopants based on current synthesis methods; thus the correlation between the true activity and the dopant configuration cannot be well understood. Another important issue about the doped graphene as ORR catalysts is that the effects of the trace amount of metal impurity remaining in the catalyst cannot be overlooked. The achievement gained in M−N−C (M = Fe and/or Co) as ORR catalyst in acid media has highlighted the importance of the metal, as the M−N4 moieties are proposed as the active sites.923,924 The proposed active sites have been identified as the FeN4 porphyrinic architectures in these doped carbons.925,926 It should be noted that there is no obvious crystalline iron structures in the doped carbon after etching,925 which means that common XRD is not enough to preclude the effect of the metal impurity. Wang et al. reported that trace Mn metallic residue originated from the Hummers’ oxidation method during the synthesis of GO or the impurity in graphite is sufficient to alter the electrocatalytic properties of the obtained rGO, as even the residue Mn is at ppm level.927 The finding emphasizes the importance of elemental analysis in revealing the active catalytic sites in doped graphene, especially for these samples declared as “metal-free” electrocatalysts. Note that the effect of the metal impurity can be precluded by the ORR poison tests, such as using CN− to poison the active sites.924,928
Besides doped graphene sheets, some other ultrathin 2D nanosheets have also been studied as ORR catalysts. For
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6271
instance, Song and co-workers reported that oxygen-incorporated and P-doped MoS2 nanosheets show good activities for ORR.929,930 The onset potentials of electrocatalysts are improved with the current density several fold higher than that of pristine MoS2. It is found that doping of heteroatoms in the MoS2 nanosheet induces the ORR selectivity from twoelectron (pristine MoS2) to nearly four-electron process. 929,930 2D metal nanoplates are also good candidates for ORR
electrocatalysts.931−933 For instance, Wang et al. reported that the Pd@Pt nanosheet with atomically smooth Pt skin on Pd shows excellent catalytic activity and stability toward the oxygen reduction reaction in an acidic electrolyte. The mass activity of the nanosheet is nearly 7-fold higher that of the commercial Pt/ C catalyst, which provides an efficient way for Pt utilization.931
The DFT calculation has predicted that 2D π-conjugated MOF nanosheets can be applied as ORR electrocatalysts, and their
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6272
catalytic activities are highly dependent on the metal centrals.934 In fact, the graphene-porphyrin MOF composite has been reported with enhanced activity for ORR in 2011.935 Miner et al. reported that the intrinsically conductive MOF, Ni3(HITP)2 (HITP = 2,3,6,7,10,11-hexaiminotriphenylene), works as a well-defined catalyst for ORR in alkaline media with the activity competitive with those most active nonplatinum group metal electrocatalysts (Figure 40).936 Note that the conductive MOF contains square planar Ni−N4 sites, the active moieties in the M−N−C catalyst. Following that finding, thinning the MOF to nanometer scale can increase the exposed active sites and further enhance their activities. MOFs themselves have been widely used as precursors for the synthesis of high-performance ORR electrocatalysts by the pyrolysis method.937−939 COFs are another flexible precursor for the synthesis of ORR catalysts due to their well-defined and tunable structure.940−943 Dai and co-workers reported that COF-derived graphene analogues by carbonization of the metal-incorporated COFs act as efficient electrocatalysts for ORR in both alkaline and acid media with a good stability and remarkable tolerances to methanol-crossover and CO-poisoning effects.940
6.2.4. Other Electrocatalytic Reactions. The anisotropic synthesis of ultrathin 2D metal nanosheets has been achieved in recent years, and their potential applications as electrocatalysts have been also widely explored.28,29,944−946 For instance, Zheng and co-workers reported that the Pd nanosheet shows excellent electrocatalytic activity for the oxidation of formic acid, and its activity is 2.5 times as active as that of the commercial Pd black.28 Freestanding Co with a thickness of 4 atomic layers has been synthesized by Xie and co-workers. They found that partially oxidized Co 4-atom-thick layers showed outstanding intrinsic activity and selectivity for CO2 reduction, producing formate in aqueous solution with a low overpotential (Figure 41).526 Note that the catalytic activity of the partially oxidized catalyst is better than that of the pure Co atomic layers, which indicates the importance of manipulating the surface oxidation state of metal catalysts. The MoS2 edge sites have been confirmed as active sites for CO2 reduction. 947 The MoS2 shows superior CO2 reduction performance as compared to noble metal-based catalysts with a high current density and low overpotential (54 mV), and the CO Faradaic efficiency increases correspondingly with the decrease of the applied potentials.947 Furthermore, the selective reduction of CO2 to CO has also been achieved on MOFs and COFs,948,949 which contain the active Co-porphyrin moieties.950 Specifically, the Co-porphyrin that contained COF shows high Faradaic efficiency (90%) and turnover numbers (up to 290 000 h−1) at pH 7 with an overpotential of −0.55 V. Note that the COF catalyst possesses a 26-fold improvement in activity as compared to the molecular Co-porphyrin complex and enhanced stability without degradation over 24 h.949 The tunable structure of MOFs and COFs enables the precise manipulation of the spatial arrangement of catalytic active centers, and the intrinsic pore structure around the active sites provides access for mass transfer. These advantages demonstrate the great potential of MOFs and COFs used as electrocatalysts, and their activity could be further enhanced if the rational design and construction of frameworks with high conductivity and dimensionality-controlled synthesis of these nanomaterials, such as ultrathin 2D nanosheets, can be achieved.

sections.heading: 6.3. Batteries
sections.text:
Rechargeable batteries, one type of important energy storage devices in our daily life, have lower cost and less environmental impact as compared to that of primary batteries. With growing demands for more powerful electronic devices, currently developed rechargeable batteries are still limited by their low energy density, short cycle life, slow charge rate, relatively high cost, fire risk, and so on. Because the properties of electrode materials significantly affect the performance of rechargeable batteries, developing novel electrode materials with novel structures and surface properties is of great importance to improve the performance of rechargeable batteries. This has been demonstrated by research in the last decades with graphite as an example.951 As the most commonly used anode for LIBs, graphite has a theoretical capacity of 372 mAh/g, which, after exfoliation, the mono/few-layer graphene nanosheet exhibited double its theoretical capacity (744 mAh/g).952 This is because both sides of the graphene nanosheet can be effectively utilized. The 2D crystalline structure of graphene holds a number of advantages as compared to graphite, such as facilitating the intercalation/deintercalation of electrolyte ions, buffering the volume expansion of electrode materials due to the elasticity of 2D nanosheet, and enhancing surface/interface lithium storage properties.953,954 Besides, the generated surface defects and sheet edges of graphene during the exfoliation process can serve as active sites for the lithium storage, which leads to a specific capacity of graphene higher than its theoretical value. Lian et al. demonstrated the graphene nanosheet exhibited a high reversible capacity of 848 mAh/g after 40 charge/discharge cycles at the current density of 100 mA/g.955 Amazingly, the boron-doped graphene showed a ultrahigh capacity up to 1327 mAh/g after 30 cycles at 50 mA/g, which is partially due to generated heteroatomic defects on doped-graphene nanosheet.956 Because of the large surface area and high electrical conductive nature of graphene, it can also be used as a matrix to prevent aggregation of other high-capacity active materials, such as metal oxides/sulfides, by forming composite electrodes, which have shown enhanced specific capacity, rate capabilities, and cycling performances.957,958
Encouraged by the successful application of graphene in LIBs, many other graphene-like 2D nanomaterials have been prepared and explored in rechargeable batteries. As a typical graphite analogue, MoS2 has a layered structure with higher theoretical capacity (670 mAh/g) based on the following lithium storage mechanism (MoS2 + 4Li
+ + 4e− ↔ Mo + 2Li2S), which has been intensively studied as the anode material for LIBs.959 Although possessing high initial capacity, bulk MoS2 normally shows a quick decay of its capacity in the subsequent charge/discharge cycles or at increased charge/ discharge rate. This phenomenon is believed due to pulverization of electrode that was caused by the large volume expansion of bulk MoS2 as well as the high energy barriers for intercalation of Li+ ions into the interlayer space of bulk MoS2. In contrast, 2D MoS2 nanosheet showed much enhanced LIB performance due to the shorter diffusion path length for Li+ ions and enlarged surface active sites.960−963 A recent report demonstrated that the 2D MoS2 nanosheet prepared by exfoliation of bulk MoS2 exhibited a reversible capacity of ∼750 mAh/g after 50 charge/discharge cycles at the current density of 50 mA/g. Similar results have also been found in other 2D nanomaterials, such as WS2, 964 VS2, 965 SnS2, 966−968 and SnO2, 969 clearly indicating the advantages and promising future of using 2D nanomaterials in rechargeable batteries. In
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6273
this section, we introduce the recent development of rechargeable batteries based on ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, with emphasis on the advantages of novel 2D nanomaterials and their composites in applications like LIBs and other nonlithium-ion batteries, such as SIBs and lithium−sulfur (Li− S) batteries. 6.3.1. Li-Ion Batteries. LIBs are one type of typical and common energy storage devices in our daily life, being well established and widely used for portable electronic devices as well as electrical vehicles.970−975 The relatively low theoretical capacity of graphite (372 mAh/g), a commercialized anode material of LIBs, has triggered the intensive research on searching the alternative anode materials with better lithium storage property. Many materials with higher theoretical capacities, such as cobalt, iron, tin-based oxides, and sulfides, have been investigated for LIBs in the past years.961,976−979 For instance, SnO2 has a theoretical capacity of 790 mAh/g, which is over twice that of graphite.979,980 Although having high theoretical capacities, those materials normally suffer from poor cycling performance, due to their large volume expansions during Li+ ion intercalation. To solve the common problem, a number of strategies have been developed to construct various complicated nanostructures, such as hollow, core−shell, and porous nanostructures. Jiang et al. reported that ultrathin SnO2 nanosheet delivered a reversible capacity of 534 mAh/g after 50 cycles at a current density of 156 mA/g when used as an anode in a LIB, which is much higher than the SnO2 nanoparticle (355 mAh/g) and hollow sphere counterparts (177 mAh/g).981 This clearly indicates the structure of electrode materials has a significant effect on their performance and also demonstrates the promising application of 2D nanomaterials for LIBs. Electrodes based on 2D nanomaterials can be classified into restacked ultrathin 2D nanosheets, hierarchical structures assembled by 2D nanosheets, and their composites. Ultrathin inorganic 2D nanosheets with single- or few-layer thickness are typical 2D nanomaterials for LIBs.964,982,983
Electrodes fabricated by restacking those ultrathin inorganic 2D nanosheets possess high surface area and edge sites that result from their unique 2D morphologies. Restacked nanosheets normally exhibited larger interlayer distance than their bulk counterparts, which not only facilitates Li+ ion insertion/ extraction, but also has more tolerance to the volume change of the electrode, therefore leading to the enhanced specific capacity and electrochemical stability. The electrode fabricated by restacking exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet delivered a reversible capacity of ∼750 mAh/g after 50 cycles at current density of 50 mA/g, much better than that of the bulk MoS2 electrode (226 mAh/g).982 The good cycling performance of restacked MoS2 electrode should be related to the enlarged spacing of MoS2 layers (0.635 nm) and high specific surface area. Zhang and coworkers reported that, when used as anode in a LIB, the CuS nanosheet delivered a specific capacity of ∼642 mAh/g after 360 cycles at 0.2 A/g, surpassing other CuS nanostructures.579 Many other inorganic 2D nanosheets have also been explored as anodes for LIBs, such as MXenes,79,984,985 metal-based nanosheets,986,987 and 2D heteronanostructures.390
Because of the vdW interaction, 2D nanomaterials tend to restack together, forming irreversible agglomerates during the electrode fabrication process, resulting in the loss of some special properties arising from their ultrathin 2D structural characteristics, such as high density of active sites and large accessible surface area. Previous studies on graphene have revealed that the fabrication of 3D porous architectures is able to effectively prevent aggregation of graphene, while in the meantime preserving the superior intrinsic properties of 2D nanosheets.988−998 The resultant 3D graphene-based materials have exhibited promising performances in a wide range of applications.992,993,997,998 Hence, creation of 3D architectures by using 2D nanomaterials as building blocks is highly expected to address the problem of aggregation, providing a promising pathway to realize practical applications of 2D nanomaterials.999,1000 It is an appealing strategy to assemble 2D nanosheets
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6274
into hierarchical 3D architectures with a variety of morphologies, for example, wires,1001 tubes,1002 boxes,1003,1004 spheres,1005−1007 and flower-like structures.1008 These 3D structures are able to effectively prevent the aggregation of 2D nanosheets, as well as largely exposing their surface area and active edge sites. In addition to preserving the intrinsic features of 2D nanomaterials, new properties also emerged from assembled 3D architectures. As a typical example, Wang and co-workers reported that the MoS2 nanotube assembled from monolayer MoS2 exhibited excellent electrochemical properties as anode material in a LIB, delivering a reversible specific capacity of 839 mAh/g after 50 cycles at 100 mA/g as well as a good rate capability of 600 mAh/g at a high current density of 5 A/g.1002
Alternatively, engineering pores on ultrathin 2D nanomaterials is also an effective way to prevent the destruction of electrode materials caused by their volume expansions as well as to shorten the Li+ ion diffusion length for improved rate capability. As a typical example, Zhao et al. reported the utilization of porous graphene nanosheet as anode in a LIB, which exhibited a highly reversible capacity of 1040 mAh/g at 100 mA/g, better than the other porous carbon-based anodes (Figure 42).1009 This strategy can also be applied to prepare other porous inorganic 2D nanomaterials. As another example, 2D macroporous Co3O4 platelet exhibited an excellent cycling performance with no obvious decrease of capacity after 30 charge/discharge cycles.1010 In contrast, the other morphologies of Co3O4, that is, nanoparticles and rod-like structure, showed quick decays of their capacities during cycling. The Co3O4 macroporous platelet also showed a good rate capability with a reversible capacity of 811 mAh/g at a discharge rate of 2 C, which benefits from the large surface area and short diffusion length for Li+ ions. Besides application for anode materials, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have also been explored as cathodes for LIBs.1011 Few-layer V2O5 nanosheet with thickness of ∼3 nm has been used as a cathode in a LIB, showing an excellent rate capability of 117 mAh/g at ultrahigh discharge rate of 50 C.1012 In contrast, the bulk V2O5 exhibits a specific capacity less than
50 mAh/g even at a relatively low rate of 10 C. A good capacity retention of ∼93.8% was also achieved on the V2O5 nanosheet electrode after 50 charge/discharge cycles at 0.2 C, as compared to the bulk counterpart (46%). The unique 2D structure provides the enhanced rate capability and electrochemical stability of V2O5 nanosheet when used as cathodes in LIBs. Similarly, electrodes based on Li2MnSiO4 and Li2FeSiO4 nanosheets exhibited good LIB performances, for example, discharge capacities of 350 and 340 mAh/g for the Li2MnSiO4 and Li2FeSiO4 nanosheet, respectively, which are much higher than those of their nanoparticle counterparts.1013
Although ultrathin 2D nanomaterials exhibited enlarged specific capacity as compared to their bulk counterparts, the high density of edge sites on 2D nanomaterials increases not only the contact resistance between active materials and current collectors, but also the electron transfer resistance among nanosheets. This results in the limited cycling performances for practical applications. Fabrication of 2D hybrid nanocomposites is another effective
way to further improve the performance of ultrathin 2D nanosheets for LIBs.997,1014−1019 Zhang and co-workers reported that MoS2-coated 3D graphene showed a high reversible capacity of 877 mAh/g at 100 mA/g after 50 cycles.997 A capacity of 466 mAh/g persists even at a high current density of 4 A/g. The in situ growth of 2D MoS2 nanoplate on the graphene surface enabled an intimate contact between them, guaranteeing an effective and fast electron transfer process. In contrast, the electrode of MoS2 powdercoated 3D graphene composite suffered from a quick decay of its capacity from 638 mAh/g to less than 100 mAh/g after 50 cycles, which can be attributed to the crack and drop of active materials caused by the large volume expansion of MoS2 powder during cycling process. It has also been reported that graphene could prevent the aggregation of 2D nanomaterials, resulting in the formation of thinner and smaller grain size of synthesized 2D nanomaterials.1016,1018 This led to the reduced energy barrier for Li+ ion intercalation and also enhanced surface/interface lithium storage properties.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6275
6.3.2. Non-Li-Ion Batteries. LIBs have been the main power sources for portable electronics, such as cellphones, laptops, and digital watches, since its first demonstration in the 1990s. Because of their clean and sustainable features, LIBs are also promising power sources for electrical vehicles. Although the perspective of LIBs is promising, it should be pointed out that there are limited amounts of lithium-containing minerals, which are unevenly distributed on Earth. This directly leads to the increased price of lithium elements, which in turn significantly affects the further extension of commercialized LIBs for electrical vehicles as well as the large-scale stationary electrical storage devices that required large lithium concentration. Therefore, the development of other types of batteries based on the cost-effective electrode materials is of great importance and priority for large-scale renewable energy storage devices. Up to now, a number of rechargeable nonLi-ion batteries have been developed due to the relatively lowcost and earth-abundant elements, such as Na-ion,1020−1024 Mgion,1025−1028 and Al-ion batteries.1029
Sodium ion batteries (SIBs) are promising and attractive alternatives to LIBs.1030 The abundant resource of sodium makes SIBs cost-effective, potentially competitive with LIBs in large-scale energy storage systems.1020,1023 The large size of sodium ions (0.102 nm in radius) renders many electrode materials for LIBs not suitable for SIBs.1031 Graphite is considered as an inactive anode material for SIBs due to its small interlayer distance that restricts the intercalation of Na+
ions. Wen et al. reported that graphite could be a promising anode material for SIBs with long cycle life after it is expended (Figure 43a), which exhibited a reversible capacity of 284 mAh/ g at 20 mA/g and a capacity retention of ∼74% after 2000 charge/discharge cycles at 100 mA/g (Figure 43b,c).1032 This work provides a cost-effective way to develop electrode materials for SIBs on the basis of the earth-abundant graphite resource. The specific capacity of the expanded graphite (284 mAh/g at 20 mA/g) is still relatively low, which is not comparable with other electrode materials, such as the exfoliated MoS2 nanosheet (386 mAh/g at 40 mA/g). 1033
In addition to expanded graphite, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have been also explored as electrode materials for SIBs, such as TMDs, MXenes,441 MoO3−x nanosheet,
1021 and BP.200 As a typical example, Chen et al. revealed that the interlayer distance of MoS2 nanosheets plays an essential role in its SIB performance.1034 The electrochemical results showed that the MoS2 nanosheet with the largest interlayer distance (0.69 nm) exhibited the best SIB performance, for example, reversible capacities of 300 and 195 mAh/g at current densities of 1 and 10 A/g after 1500 cycles, respectively. This indicates that the enlarged interlayer distance of MoS2 benefits the enhanced electrochemical stability of the electrode and also leads to the fast reaction kinetics, which allows for an easier intercalation/ deintercalation of Na+ ions into the MoS2 structure. The BP nanosheet has also been demonstrated for SIBs.200 Note that BP has a high electrical conductivity (∼300 S/m) and large
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6276
theoretical specific capacity (2596 mAh/g). It has a channel length of 3.08 Å, large enough for the diffusion of Na+ ions, which is also much larger than that of graphite (1.86 Å) (Figure 44a).200 Cui and co-workers reported the utilization of a fewlayer BP nanosheet with thickness of 2−5 nm as the electrode for SIBs.977 The electrode was prepared by mixing phosphorene with graphene to form a BP-graphene hybrid with a sandwiched structure (Figure 44b−d).200 The incorporated graphene can serve as an elastic buffer to prevent the large volume expansion of the electrode material (∼500%) due to the formation of Na3P alloy during the sodiation process. As a result, the hybrid electrode showed an ultrahigh capacity of 2440 mAh/g at a rate of 0.02 C (Figure 44e),200 which is close to the theoretical specific value of BP for SIBs (2596 mAh/g). The hybrid electrode exhibited a good cycling property with ∼85% retention of its initial discharge capacity at 0.02 C after 100 cycles. Even at a large rate of 10 C, a capacity retention of 77% still remained, indicating the good electrochemical stability. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have also been investigated in lithium−sulfur (Li−S) batteries. Li−S batteries possess a high energy density up to 2600 Wh/kg, making it a promising candidate for non-LIB energy storage applications with high theoretical capacity of 1675 mAh/g based on the redox reaction of S + 2Li+ + 2e− ↔ Li2S.
1035,1036 The natural abundance of sulfur resources also makes Li−S batteries cost-effective and sustainable as compared to LIBs. The performance of currently developed Li−S batteries still suffered from poor cycling properties despite the concept of Li−S batteries that has been demonstrated for over 30 years. One significant issue that limits the practical application of Li−S batteries is the polysulfide dissolution during the charge/discharge process, that is, the “shuttle effect”. In a typical Li−S battery, the intermediate lithium polysulfide (Li2Sn, n = 4−6) was formed during the charge/discharge process, which can be dissolved in the electrolyte and transported back and forth between electrodes. This side reaction not only induces the loss of electrode material, but also leads to the passivation of cathode surface, resulting in a low Coulombic efficiency and rapid capacity decrease during cycling process of Li−S batteries. To solve this “shuttle effect”, the development of novel electrode materials/ structures that have strong interaction with S and firmly anchor S on the electrode is essential to achieve a high cycling property of Li−S batteries. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials featuring high surface area and plenty of active sites on both basal planes and edges can effectively confine S through chemical bonding or physical adsorption. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with large lateral sizes could also suppress shuttle effects by entrapping the polysulfide and preventing it from dissolving in the electrolyte, which makes ultrathin 2D nanomaterials promising for Li−S batteries. Carbon-based 2D nanomaterials have been demonstrated as promising host materials for Li−S batteries due to the affinity of carbon to sulfur.1037 Graphene with a high specific surface area (∼2600 m2/g), ultrahigh electrical conductivity, and excellent structure stability has been intensively studied for Li−S batteries. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials can restrict the polysulfide dissolution by the formation of chemical bonds or physical adsorption between ultrathin 2D nanomaterials and sulfur element. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials are able to trap the formed Li2Sn within the interlayer spacing, which serve as good physical entrappers.1038,1039 Taking graphene as a typical example, the formed sandwich-like structure of graphene/S
composite showed a reversible capacity of ∼505 mAh/g at rate of 1C (1680 mA/g) and a capacity retention of 75% over 100 cycles.1038 In addition, the functional groups on GO sheets play an important role in anchoring S atoms through forming chemical bonds between them, such as O−S bonds. The oxygenated functional groups can effectively prevent the formed Li2Sn species from dissolving into the electrolyte during cycling.1040 It is also found that graphene sheets doped by heteroatoms, such as N, B, and S atoms, have strong ionic interactions with Li2Sn, thus inhibiting its dissolution in the electrolyte.1041
Apart from forming chemical bonds with S, ultrathin 2D nanomaterials can also serve as a physical trapper to stabilize the cathode materials of Li−S batteries by wrapping them. Wang et al. demonstrated that the graphene-wrapped sulfur nanoparticle exhibited a high specific capacity of ∼600 mAh/g after 100 charge/discharge cycles.1042 Later, a similar strategy was also applied to TMDs, in which TMD nanosheets served as host materials.1043 In this work, TMD thin films, that is, TiS2, ZrS2, and VS2, were coated onto Li2S nanoparticles to form corresponding Li2S@TMD core−shell nanostructures (Figure 45a,b).1043 The resultant TMD films acted as the physical
barrier of Li2S to prevent its dissolution in the electrolyte. Different from the graphene shell, a chemical bonding between Li2S and TiS2 with a high binding energy of 2.99 eV can be formed (Figure 45c), minimizing the “shuttle effect”.1043 As a result, the cathode of Li2S@TiS2 composite showed an excellent cycling behavior with a capacity retention of 77% after charging and discharging it at 583 mA/g for 400 cycles. It also exhibited a good rate capability, for example, reversible capacity of 700 and 503 mAh/g at rates of 0.2 and 4 C, respectively (Figures 45d).1043 Because of the large members of 2D TMD nanosheets, it can be expected that promising host materials for Li−S batteries could be found in the family of 2D TMDs. MXenes have also been used for Li−S batteries.443 After incorporation of S element into Ti2C using a heat treatment, a strong interaction between them was established by forming
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6277
the S−Ti−C bonding, which was confirmed by XPS.443 The resultant S−Ti2C hybrid with a sulfur concentration of 70 wt % delivered a high reversible capacity of 723 mAh/g after 650 charge/discharge cycles. It is worthy to note that the cycling performance is comparable to those of other reported host materials, such as N,S-doped graphene.443 At a high rate of 4 C, a specific capacity of 660 mAh/g still remained for the S−Ti2C hybrid electrode. It was believed that the good performance of the hybrid electrode is attributed to a combined factor of high stability and electrical conductivity of the S−Ti2C hybrid.443 On the one hand, the strong interaction between Ti2C and formed Li2Sn inhibits the loss of active materials, leading to the improved cycling performance. The metallic properties of Ti2C also benefit the high-rate performance of S−Ti2C hybrid electrode due to its high electrical conductivity. Mesoporous 2D nanomaterials are another kind of promising host materials for Li−S batteries, which have shown improved performances.1044,1045 Sulfur nanoparticles trapped within the pores of 2D nanomaterials are more stable, as compared to those coated on the exterior surface of 2D nanomaterials and directly exposed to the electrolyte. Apart from the minimized “shuttle effect” of Li2Sn by forming strong interaction between pore edges and sulfur, the high electrical conductivity and elastic matrix of some mesoporous 2D nanomaterials (e.g., graphene) can also promote the high-rate performance of Li−S batteries.1045 The nanoporous graphene with pore size of ∼3.8 nm was fabricated by chemical activation of rGO using KOH and then used as the host material for Li−S batteries.1044 Sulfur can be encapsulated into pores of graphene by a melt diffusion process. Because of the strong affinity of sulfur to carbon, sulfur nanoparticles were constrained inside the nanopores of the graphene sheet, which limits the diffusion of formed Li2Sn
species. Each pore can act as a “micro-reactor” that accommodates the volume expansion of sulfur, giving rise to improved cycling stabilities, for example, a capacity retention of 74% at 1 C after 100 cycles. Mesoporous 2D nanomaterials are not only limited to graphene. Zhang et al. reported the use of 2D oxygenated carbon nitride (OCN) nanosheet for Li−S batteries.1046 The resultant OCN nanosheet is of mesoporous structure with a pore size of 1−2 nm thus and has a high surface area up to 605.97 m2/g. The OCN nanosheet is also full of oxygenated functional groups (e.g., −C−OH, −COOH, and −C−O−C) on its surface (Figure 46a,b).1046 The N concentration in the OCN nanosheet (20.49 wt %) is much higher than those of the N-doped graphene sheet, therefore having substantive active sites for anchoring the polysulfide. As expected, after the incorporation of S on the OCN nanosheet, the fabricated cathode of S/OCN hybrid with S concentration of 56 wt % delivered a reversible discharge capacity of 447.3 mAh/g after charging/discharging for 500 cycles, which is better than the g-C3N4 (Figure 46c).
1046 After the S/OCN cathode was tested for 2000 cycles, a reversible capacity of 230.7 mAh/g still remained. It is noteworthy that mesoporous TMD nanosheets have not been reported for Li−S batteries yet. The nanosized pores within TMD nanosheets may provide abundant edge sites of metallic centers that can form strong interaction with sulfur through metal−S bonds, which may effectively confine the polysulfide within these nanopores. Considering the large number of familiar members of TMDs, there might be many potential host materials for Li−S batteries. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have shown promising applications in energy storage devices with much improved specific capacity, rate capability, and cycling performance as compared to their bulk counterparts. There are still some challenges in
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6278
this research field. Low initial Coulombic efficiencies are commonly observed for most of the rechargeable batteries based on electrodes constructed from ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, leading to a great loss of specific capacity. Although ultrathin 2D nanomaterials exhibited improved capacity as compared to many traditional electrode materials, their electrochemical stabilities are still required to be further explored when considering their practical applications. Because most of the reported ultrathin 2D nanomaterials were tested in limited charge/discharge cycles (e.g., <100 cycles), there proofof-concept applications are still far behind practical demands. Because of the high surface area of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, the formation of a thick solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) may result in the decrease of Li+ ion concentration in the electrolyte and thus the increase of resistance, leading to a large irreversible capacity and decreased LIB performance. Therefore, optimizing the SEI formation process is still required. Because the performance of batteries is highly reliant on their electrode materials, more efforts on the exploration of novel 2D nanomaterials and design of new structured electrodes are necessary too. (1) A number of 2D nanomaterials have been prepared via various synthetic approaches, such as hydrothermal and exfoliation methods; however, the resultant 2D nanomaterials have a high tendency to form corresponding restacked films. This results in the loss of a series of unique properties of 2D nanomaterials, such as high specific surface area, active sites, and accessibility toward the electrolyte. Developing 2D nanosheets with in-plane pores might be an effective way to address the restacking issue of 2D nanomaterials and provide more diffusion pathways for the electrolyte as well as active sites. Their scalable production and structural stability are still a concern. Besides, it might be an interesting research direction to develop scalable preparation approaches for some novel 2D nanomaterials and explore their applications in energy storage devices, such as silicene,1047,1048 germanene,1049 and ternary inorganic nanosheets.387 The development of novel electrode materials should be not compromised by a large waste of raw materials and the deteriorating effects to our environment. (2) It might be also promising to develop electrode materials with new structures and investigate their energy storage applications, such as the vertically grown 2D nanomaterials (e.g., MoSe2 and WSe2) on current collector. 775 The well-aligned vertical nanosheets possess largely accessible surface and edge sites, which are able to create direct diffusion pathways for electrolyte ions and store charges with a uniform distribution on the interface of electrode/electrolyte. A direct contact to current collector can also facilitate electron transport, therefore reducing the inner resistance of the electrode.

sections.heading: 6.4. Supercapacitors
sections.text:
Supercapacitors are one kind of promising energy storage device with the typical characteristics of high power density, fast charge/discharge rate (e.g., several seconds), excellent cycling life (e.g., 10 000 cycles), low cost, and safe operation conditions. As seen in Figure 47, the Ragone plot shows that supercapacitors also possess much higher power density (e.g., several thousands of W/kg) comparable to batteries and conventional capacitors, but having lower energy density.1050 Therefore, one of the tasks for the current development of supercapacitors is to achieve a proper balance between the energy and power density. In another word, an ideal highperformance supercapacitor is expected to possess enhanced energy density without the compromise of its power density.
According to the surface charge-storage mechanism of supercapacitors, two key factors, that is, surface area and electrical conductivity, affect the supercapacitor performance of electrode materials. Bearing this in mind, numerous efforts have been devoted to developing advanced electrode materials through various strategies, such as rational design of nano/ microstructured materials with defined pore size/structure, surface engineering and functionalization of electrode materials, as well as the preparation of composites depending on the combination of highly electrical conductive materials and faradaic materials.1050−1052
Activated carbon (AC) is one of the first studied electrode materials for supercapacitors that has been commercialized. AC stores charges on the basis of the typical electric double-layer capacitor (EDLC) mechanism.1053 Depending on the preparation and activation methods, AC may be synthesized as a porous structure with ultrahigh surface area (e.g., 3000 m2/ g).1054 Although having a high surface area, the broad pore size distribution and high density of inaccessible pores for electrolyte ions of ACs result in a low specific capacitance (e.g., <10 μF/cm2), which is much lower than the theoretical capacitance of EDLCs (15−25 mF/cm2).1055,1056 A number of surface functional groups generated during the activation process on ACs also lead to their poor electrical conductivities and instable electrochemical performances, especially when organic electrolytes were used.1057,1058 For other EDLC materials, such as CNTs1059 and activated carbon fibers,1060 the fabrication of these materials is normally expensive and complicated, limiting their practical usages. For instance, CNTs are normally synthesized by the CVD method, which requires a subsequent purification process to remove metallic catalysts, increasing the cost of using CNTs for supercapacitor electrodes.
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6279
Aside from EDLC materials, electrode materials with faradaic redox behavior, such as the pseudocapacitive materials of RuO2 1061 and MnO2, 1062 are some of the typical supercapacitor materials used to store charges based on the faradaic redox reaction on the electrode surface and contribute to the pseudocapacitance. This kind of electrode material can deliver much higher capacitance than EDLCs, but suffers from poor cycling stability due to their relatively low electrical conductivities. For RuO2, its high cost is another concern for practical usage. Similar to EDLC materials, to efficiently utilize the surface redox reaction, developing nanostructured faradaic electrode materials with low cost, high density of active sites, easily accessible surface area, and short diffusion path length for electrolyte ions are effective ways to achieve high-performance supercapacitors. The cost, scalability, and reproducibility of these nanostructured materials are also of concern when developing such a strategy. Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials have been intensively studied for supercapacitors.152,156,439,1063 As discussed above, the high surface area and electrical conductivity of electrode materials significantly affected their supercapacitor performances. In principle, due to the ultrathiness and large lateral size, 2D nanomaterials with single- or few-layer thickness have high surface areas that are more easily accessible from both sides, as compared to other nanostructured materials. Some 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene and MXenes, also have ultrahigh electrical mobility that benefits the high-rate performance, rendering them promising materials for supercapacitors. In this section, we summarize the recent progress of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials for supercapacitors. 6.4.1. Graphene-Based Supercapacitors. Graphene is a typical 2D nanomaterial that possesses both high surface area (up to 2630 m2/g) and high charge mobility (∼10 000 cm2 V−1 s−1), suitable for supercapacitors.1064 Because of the unique properties and special structure of graphene, its theoretical capacitance is up to 550 F/g,1065,1066 surpassing many other types of carbon materials. However, graphene has a high tendency to aggregate and form the close-packed graphitic structure due to the van der Waals interaction between their sheets, resulting in the loss of some unique properties that arise from the 2D morphology of graphene, for example, high surface area. The aggregation of graphene also leads to the decrease of an efficient mass transfer pathway and accessible surface area for the electrolyte, leading to a poor rate performance. In another word, fast charge/discharge rate and high power density, which are the most typical characteristics of graphenebased supercapacitors, are deteriorating due to the aggregation of graphene. Therefore, many efforts have been devoted to solving the restacking issue of graphene and developing highperformance graphene-based electrodes for supercapacitors in the past few years. These strategies mainly include (1) fabrication of graphene electrodes with varied porous morphologies, such as foams, networks, fibers, spheres, and hydro/aerogels;1067−1071 (2) introduction of varied “spacer” materials, such as carbon nanomaterials,1072−1074 nanodiamonds,1075 and metal nanocrystals,1076 to separate graphene sheets within thin film electrodes; and (3) the preparation of graphene with in-plane pores.1009 In comparison to the stacked graphene films, those porous graphene electrodes have a higher surface area (e.g., ∼850 m2/g for the 3D graphene networks prepared by the CVD method989), which possess more pathways for the transportation of electrolyte ions and facilitate their access to the surface of each graphene sheet, therefore
exhibiting better supercapacitor performances. As a typical example, Choi et al. prepared the graphene film with a macroporous structure by using the polystyrene as the template and then used it as an electrode for supercapacitors.1077 The resultant porous graphene electrode delivered a specific capacitance of 202 F/g at a current density of 1 A/g, higher than that of the stacked graphene film electrode (93 F/g). Even at a very large charge/discharge current density of 35 A/g, the porous graphene electrode still exhibits a high specific capacitance, which is 97.7% of the value measured at 0.5 A/g. Alternatively, engineering in-plane pores on graphene sheets is another promising way to fabricate high-performance supercapacitor electrodes. Those in-plane pores on graphene sheets are able to promote accessibility of electrolytes to the whole electrode material by enabling transportation of ions through the top layer of stacked graphene film to its bottom layer, thus improving the rate capability. As a typical example, Ruoff and co-workers reported the preparation of in-plane porous graphene sheets by the chemical activation of GO sheets using KOH at 800 °C, which showed an ultrahigh surface area of 3100 m2 g−1, exceeding the theoretical value of graphene (2630 m2/g).1078 The symmetrical supercapacitor fabricated based on these porous graphene sheets delivered a specific capacitance of 150 F g−1 at current density of 0.8 A g−1 in the organic electrolyte of tetraethylammoniumtetrafluoroborate/acetonitrile (TEA BF4/AN). Duan et al. developed a relatively more convenient method to fabricate in-plane porous graphene sheets for supercapacitors.1079 In this work, H2O2 was used as the etchant and reacted with GO sheets in a hydrothermal tank, resulting in graphene hydrogels with inplane porous graphene sheets. The symmetrical supercapacitor fabricated on the basis of these porous graphene sheets delivered a specific capacitance of 298 F/g at 1 A/g in the 1- ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate/AN (EMIMBF4/ AN) electrolyte. Other kinds of nanoporous graphene sheets have also been prepared1009,1078,1080−1083 as potential building blocks for graphene-based supercapacitors. It can be anticipated that supercapacitors with much more enhanced performance might be obtained after optimizing the correlation between performance of those in-plane porous graphene sheets and their intrinsic properties, for example, pore size and its distribution, wettability, and surface functional groups. Porous graphene electrodes fabricated using the aforementioned strategies can effectively solve the restacking problem of graphene sheets and create electrical conductive networks for fast transfer charges utilizing the unique properties of graphene, that is, high surface area and electrical conductivity. Because of their porous nature, those graphene materials normally show limited volumetric energy and power density. Therefore, for compact energy storage and conversion devices applications, it is still challenging to fabricate high-performance graphene electrodes with high packing density. Li et al. developed graphene film electrodes with high packing density and then used it for supercapacitors.148,1084 In their work, the stacked graphene film containing a mixture of H2O/H2SO4 was first prepared by the filtration method, which was then heated to remove the H2O. The H2SO4 molecules remaining between graphene sheets not only acted as the electrolyte, but also served as “spacer” materials to prevent the aggregation of graphene sheets. The resultant graphene film electrode exhibited a packing density up to 1.33 g/cm3, higher than those of other porous graphene films (0.05−0.75 g/ cm3).1085,1086 This method provided a convenient, efficient,
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6280
and scalable way to fabricate high-packing-density graphene films and enabled direct integration of the obtained graphene films into supercapacitor devices. We believe this method can also be used to fabricate thin film electrodes made of other 2D nanosheets for high-performance supercapacitors. Besides the fabrication of porous graphene electrodes, there are also several other strategies to improve the supercapacitor performance of graphene: introducing foreign atoms with active redox species (e.g., N, O, S, B, and P) into graphene1087,1088 and fabrication of graphene composites with other highly electrochemical active materials1089 (e.g., Ni(OH)2 nanoplates1090 and MnO2 nanosheets
1091). 6.4.2. Other 2D Nanomaterial-Based Supercapacitors. Inspired by the success of graphene, a number of other 2D nanosheets have also been used for supercapacitors. Those 2D nanomaterials include 2D nanosheets of metal oxides/ hydroxides, TMDs, MXenes, and so on. Aside from storing charges based on EDLCs, some 2D nanomaterials also have a reversible faradaic process, such as surface redox reactions and electrochemical doping/dedoping, to generate higher energy densities. Because of the unique 2D structure, surface redox reactions can occur on both sides of 2D nanomaterials, therefore contributing more faradaic capacitance as compared to their bulk counterparts. RuO2-based materials are typical pseudocapacitor materials with a high theoretical capacitance of 2000 F/g and good electrical conductivity, wide voltage windows, long cycle life,
and high chemical stability.1061 To efficiently utilize the surface redox reactions of RuO2, Sugimoto et al. prepared a 2D RuO2 nanosheet by exfoliation of a layered ruthenic acid. The resulting nanosheets exhibited a high specific capacitance of 658 F/g at 2 mV/s when used as the electrode for supercapacitors.1092 This value is much higher than that of the bulk RuO2. Because the high cost of RuO2 significantly limits its practical usage, other affordable faradaic materials have been developed, such as MnO2, Co3O4, and Ni(OH)2. Their large theoretical capacity (e.g., 3560 F/g for Co3O4
1093) and relatively low cost make them promising alternatives to the RuO2 for supercapacitors. Those materials with 2D morphologies, such as nanosheets and nanoplates, can be simply fabricated through a number of cost-effective synthetic routes (e.g., hydrothermal method).1094 As compared to particles, 2D nanosheets have a shorter diffusion length for electrolyte ions, which benefits the redox reaction during the rapid charge/ discharge process. The β-Co(OH)2 nanosheet prepared by exfoliation of the α-Co(OH)2 nanocone delivered a specific capacitance of 1197 F/g at a current density of 1 A/g.1063 The poor electrical conductivity and small voltage window of these materials (e.g., ∼0.5 V for Ni and Co-based hydroxides1063) are still an issue for their practical applications. Conductive polymers, such as polyaniline (PANI), polypyrrole (PPy), and poly(3,4-ethylenedioxythiophene) (PEDOT), are another kind of attractive electrode material for supercapacitors, which store charges through the electro-
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6281
chemical doping/dedoping process.1095,1096 These electrode materials also possess the advantages of good conductivity, high reversible redox activity, low cost, and easy preparation. 2D PANI nanosheet has been synthesized by the chemical oxidative polymerization method using ice as the hard template.1097 This novel 2D conductive polymer has unique 2D conducting pathways with conductivity of 35 S/cm and a high surface-to-volume ratio, which might exhibit interesting electrochemical properties as compared to other morphologies of conductive polymers. Although the aforementioned 2D faradaic nanomaterials have shown relatively higher specific capacitances and energy density, attributed to the reversible surface redox process, they normally exhibited lower power densities and poorer electrochemical stabilities as compared to the EDLC materials. This is due to their poor electric conductivities that restrain fast electron transfer as well as their unstable structures during the reversible faradaic process. Recent developments in the synthesis of novel ultrathin 2D nanomaterials with different compositions and properties have provided a variety of candidates for supercapacitors. Most of these ultrathin 2D nanomaterials were prepared by exfoliation of bulk crystals to produce a large quantity of 2D nanosheets and are favorable for energy storage applications. Freestanding thin films can be easily fabricated through filtration methods without extra binders and then used directly as electrodes, improving the overall energy density of fabricated devices. Chhowalla and co-workers reported a thin film electrode composed of 1T-phase MoS2 (1T-MoS2) nanosheet for highperformance supercapacitors (Figure 48a,b).152 The 1T-MoS2 nanosheet-based electrode delivered an ultrahigh capacitance of 650 F/cm3 in an H2SO4 aqueous electrolyte (Figure 48c,d). 152 This value is among the highest for TMD-based supercapacitor electrodes.152 The 1T-MoS2 electrode also showed remarkably
high volumetric energy and power densities that are comparable to those of many other types of electrode materials, such as porous graphene and activated carbon (Figure 48e).152 It is worth mentioning that 2H-MoS2 has been considered as an unsuitable electrode material for supercapacitors because of its relatively low specific capacitance (e.g., 129.2 F/g at 1 A/g1098). To that end, good supercapacitor performance of the 1T-MoS2 electrode might be due to the following reasons: (1) 1T-MoS2 has a high electrical conductivity of 10−100 S/cm, which is ∼107 times higher than that of 2H-phase MoS2 (2H-MoS2) and also comparable with the rGO film.152 (2) The intrinsic hydrophilicity of 1T-MoS2 nanosheet enhanced the wettability of thin film electrode to the electrolyte. (3) The restacked 1TMoS2 nanosheet provided multiple channels for easy intercalation of various electrolyte ions, for example, H+ ions, resulting in a high specific capacitance. This work opens a new avenue to utilize 2D MoS2 nanosheets for high-performance supercapacitors. A possible future direction might be to engineer the phase of other 2D TMDs, obtaining their metallic phases, and then investigate their supercapacitor performance. Benefiting from the high conductivity, the 1T-MoS2 nanosheet has also been used as a conductive substrate for the decoration of other active materials and then used for supercapacitors. Tang and co-workers fabricated polypyrrole-coated 1T-MoS2 nanosheet, which showed a high specific capacitance of 665 F/g at a current density of 0.5 A/g.1099 The composite electrode also delivered a high energy density of 83.3 Wh/kg at a power density of ∼3.3 kW/kg. MXenes are another type of promising electrode materials that can store extra charges through intercalation of electrolyte ions into their interlayer spaces.199,437,1100 One of the distinct advantages of MXenes is their extremely high electrical conductivities (e.g., 4.3 × 105 S/m for 28 nm-thick Ti3C2 film1100) as compared to the other 2D nanomaterials beyond
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6282
graphene, such as 2D metal hydroxides and TMDs. This unique property of MXenes guarantees high charge-transfer efficiency when they are used as supercapacitor electrodes. For example, Ti3C2 nanosheet is full of surface functional groups (e.g., −OH, −F) generated in the etch process using HF,437 making them hydrophilic with excellent wettability in aqueous electrolytes. Their large interlayer distances resulting from the removal of Al atoms can provide 2D transport pathways for the efficient diffusion of aqueous electrolyte ions and even organic ions, exhibiting high specific capacitance even at a high discharge rate. The freestanding paper composed of Ti3C2Tx nanosheet (Figure 49a; T denotes the surface functional groups on the MXene nanosheet, such as −OH and −F) delivered an ultrahigh volumetric capacitance of 900 F/cm3 at a scan rate of 2 mV/s (Figure 49b−d).199 Even at a high scan rate of 100 mV/s, good volumetric capacitance was still maintained at ∼700 F/cm3 (Figure 49c).199 Almost no degradation of capacitance was observed for the Ti3C2Tx paper, even after 10 000 charge/discharge cycles. MXenes can also be mixed with poly(vinyl alcohol) (PVA) to obtain the composite electrode with high flexibility and enhanced cationic intercalation property for supercapacitors.1100 The unique characteristics of MXenes, including rich chemical components, tunable electronic conductivities, and multiple surface functionalities, make them promising as supercapacitor electrodes. Most of the current reports focused on the Ti3C2 nanosheet, and it would be beneficial to investigate the other MXenes and explore their supercapacitor performances. Engineering the surface functional groups of MXenes is still necessary to make them compatible to organic electrolytes, which holds the achievement for high voltage window and energy density. There has been rapid progress on the utilization of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials beyond graphene for supercapacitors in the past few years. It is worth noting that this research area is still at its very beginning. Most of the synthesized ultrathin 2D nanosheets normally exhibited semiconducting nature with low electrical conductivity. A more complicated process of hybrid-
ization with carbon materials may be required to achieve an enhanced conductivity, thus increasing the fabrication cost and influencing the scalability and reproducibility of the products. Because a large surface area and high electrical conductivity are two key factors for high-performance supercapacitors, a future direction may be toward exploring novel 2D nanomaterials featuring both high conductivity and large surface area for supercapacitors. The large family of inorganic 2D nanomaterials provides numerous options to the highly electrical conducting 2D nanosheets. It is also promising to develop novel methods that convert existing 2D nanomaterials to their highly conductive counterparts.
6.4.3. Ultrathin 2D Nanomaterial-Based Flexible Supercapacitors. Flexible supercapacitors, able to be bended and rolled up, are one of the most prospective candidates of power supplies for the next-generation wearable devices based on electronic papers and textiles.1101−1103 Benefiting from the unique characteristics of 2D nanomaterials (i.e., ultrathin thickness, large lateral size, and good mechanical flexibility), they have been considered as promising building blocks for the fabrication of flexible supercapacitors. In the past few years, graphene-based electrodes with various morphologies, such as freestanding thin films, papers, and aerogels, have been intensively studied for flexible supercapacitors, due to the high conductivity and mechanical flexibility of graphene.1104 Within those electrodes, graphene acted as both the active material and the current collector to be used directly or after hybridization with other materials. In this section, we focus on the introduction of flexible supercapacitors constructed by ultrathin 2D nanomaterials beyond graphene, such as TMDs, MXenes, and metal hydroxides/oxides. On the basis of the device configuration, 2D nanomaterial-based flexible supercapacitors can be classified into three main categories: flexible supercapacitors with a sandwich-like structure, planar supercapacitors, and fiber-based supercapacitors. The sandwich-type supercapacitors are the most common configuration of flexible energy storage devices (Figure
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6283
50a).156,991 Depending on the active materials used on two electrodes, this type of supercapacitor can be further divided into symmetric supercapacitors (the same electrode materials) and hybrids (different kinds of electrode materials). The electrode can be fabricated by coating active materials on conductive flexible substrates, such as the gold-coated polyethylene terephthalate (PET) substrate.1105 Because of the simple device structure, sandwich-type supercapacitors can be easily fabricated and are suitable to a variety of active materials. One of the disadvantages of these supercapacitors is the poor adhesion of active materials to the current collector (i.e., conductive flexible substrates). During repeated bending cycles, active materials would normally peel off from the current collector, leading to severe degradation of the device performance. This problem might be addressed by using 2D nanosheets, which possess high surface area and large lateral size, as electrode materials with a large contact area and enhanced interaction with the current collector as compared to their bulk counterparts.1104 Therefore, flexible electrodes made of 2D nanomaterials are highly expected to exhibit more stable electrochemical properties under bending states. As a typical example, a symmetric flexible supercapacitor was fabricated by Xie and co-workers on the basis of the hybrid of graphene and vanadyl phosphate (VOPO4) nanosheet with less than 6 layers.156 The resultant device delivered a high specific capacitance of 8.36 mF/cm2 (i.e., volumetric capacitance of 928.9 F/cm3) at a current density of 0.2 A/m2. The performance is among the highest of the reported thin filmbased flexible supercapacitors, including carbon nanomaterials and metal hydroxides/sulfides.156
Relying on the van der Waals interaction between 2D nanosheets, freestanding thin films/papers have also been fabricated, such as Ti3C2 199 and 1T-MoS2 152 papers. The peeling off issue that was usually reported for sandwich-type supercapacitors can be well addressed by directly using the freestanding 2D nanomaterial-based films/papers as both active materials and current collectors.1106 Without the use of metallic current collectors and polymer binders, which both increase the total weight of device but have no contribution to capacitance, the energy density of the whole device can be improved. Planar supercapacitors composed of microelectrodes are another type of promising energy storage device for microelectronics due to their miniature sizes (Figure 50b).147,345,1107,1108 The defined gap distance between microelectrodes is also able to prevent short circuiting of supercapacitors during bending. The small distance between the two electrodes also shortens the diffusion path length of the electrolyte ions, which offers excellent rate capability for planar supercapacitors as compared to sandwich-type supercapacitors. The transportation of electrolyte ions is not affected when the device is bended, enabling a much more stable electrochemical performance. For electrodes constructed by 2D nanomaterials, electrolyte ions can diffuse through the edge of the 2D nanosheets to their interlayer spaces, where the unique 2D transport channels for electrolyte ions are formed to efficiently utilize the surface of each 2D nanosheet, leading to excellent rate capabilities even with high loading mass of electrode materials (Figure 50c).1108 As a typical example, Xie and coworkers prepared a thin film composed of the exfoliated VS2 nanosheet, which can be repeatedly bended and extended for 200 cycles without an obvious distortion of electrical properties.345 After a planar supercapacitor was fabricated using a 150 nm-thick VS2 film, the device delivered a specific
capacitance of 4.760 mF/cm2, corresponding to a volumetric capacitance of 317 F/cm3. Other kinds of 2D nanomaterials can also be used to construct planar supercapacitors with expected high performance after the exploration of a variety of 2D nanomaterials and optimization of the device configurations, such as loading of active materials, gap distance of microelectrodes, and composition of solid electrolytes. Fiber-based supercapacitors are another type of promising energy storage device with some unique properties that arise from the quasi-1D structure, such as high flexibility, stretchability, and large bending angle (Figure 50d).1109−1112 Fiber-based supercapacitors can be easily integrated into current woven techniques. Therefore, it is promising for nextgeneration wearable devices, such as electronic cloths and skins. 2D nanomaterials with a large lateral size and ultrathin dimension are ideal building blocks for the fabrication of fiber-based supercapacitors, combining the function of the active material and current collector in one electrode.1111−1113 Fibers based on graphene and its hybrids have been well developed for flexible supercapacitors in the past few years.1114 Zhang and co-workers fabricated a composite fiber of MoS2 nanosheet, rGO, and MWCNT through a wet-spinning method, which was then used to fabricate flexible supercapacitors.1111 The resultant device exhibited a very stable electrochemical performance under bending state with a specific capacitance of 5.2 F/cm3 at a current density of 0.16 A/cm3. It should be pointed out that there are few reports about fiber-based supercapacitors constructed by pure 2D nanomaterials beyond graphene. This might be due to the relatively low yield and semiconducting nature of the majority of currently available graphene analogues. Their relatively low conductivities impede the formation of efficient and fast electron transportation during the rapid charge/discharge process of supercapacitors. It might be an interesting direction to use some conductive 2D nanomaterials, such as MXenes and metallic TMD nanosheets, as building blocks to fabricate fiberbased supercapacitors. Phase engineering of semiconducting nanosheets to 1T-phase conductive ones is another interesting way to obtain high electrically conductive fibers for supercapacitors.

sections.heading: 6.5. Solar Cells
sections.text:
Utilization of solar energy is a feasible way to solve the environmental problems caused by the fossil fuel consumption and fulfill the renewable energy requirement in modern society.1115,1116 Electricity generation by solar photovoltaic technology has attracted great attention in the past decades.1117 Ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, such as graphene and TMDs, have been widely integrated as functional components in photovoltaic devices because of their fascinating electronic and optical properties.1118 In a previous review article, we already summarized the latest development of graphene-based nanomaterials for solar cell applications.198 In this Review, we mainly emphasize the use of other ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, for example, 2D TMDs, for solar cell devices.
6.5.1. Graphene-Based Transparent Conductive Electrodes. Recent years have witnessed the diverse applications of graphene in solar cell devices.1116,1119 Because of its high optical transparency and electrical conductivity, the most promising application of graphene is to serve as a transparent electrode to replace traditional transparent conductive oxide electrodes, such as indium tin oxide (ITO) and fluorine tin oxide (FTO).1120,1121 Furthermore, the mechanical flexibility
DOI: 10.1021/acs.chemrev.6b00558 Chem. Rev. 2017, 117, 6225−6331
6284
and chemical stability of graphene make it suitable for flexible photovoltaic devices.88,1122 Graphene prepared by either CVD growth or liquid exfoliation can be used to fabricate transparent electrodes. The former method has the advantages to obtain high-quality and large-scale graphene on specific substrates, while the latter approach is able to realize mass production of graphene. Considering the intrinsic conductivity of pure graphene is not high enough, impurity doping or hybridization with second additives such as carbon nanotube, conductive polymers, and metal nanowires can increase the conductivity but not at the expense of transmittance.1123−1126
In 2008, Wang et al. first reported the utilization of graphene films as transparent window electrodes for solid-state dyesensitized solar cells (DSSCs).1127 They prepared the graphene films from an aqueous GO dispersion via vacuum filtration with a subsequent thermal reduction. The obtained graphene exhibited an electrical conductivity of 550 S cm−1 and transparency of more than 70% in the wavelength range of 1000−3000 nm. A solid-state DSSC with a configuration of graphene/TiO2/dye/spiro-OMeTAD/Au was fabricated and gave a power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 0.26%, much lower than that of the FTO-based solid-state DSSC (0.84%). In this report, the key point is to replace the FTO with graphene. Although the photovoltaic performance is unsatisfactory, the result paved the way for the development of graphene transparent electrodes for solar cell devices, including CdTe thin film solar cells, organic photovoltaic (OPV) cells, and Schottky junction solar cells.1128−1131 A CdTe solar cell device with structure of glass/graphene/ZnO/CdS/CdTe/(graphite paste) exhibited a PCE of 4.17% by using CVD-grown graphene as the front transparent electrode. Graphene-based transparent conductive electrodes can be applied as both anodes and cathodes in OPVs.198 Zhang and co-workers successfully used rGO films as transparent conductive electrodes.197,1132 They could be implemented either as the anode in the OPV device with a configuration of PET/rGO/ PEDOT:PSS/(P3HT:PCBM)/TiO2/Al, which demonstrated outstanding flexibility, or as the cathode with a layered structure of quartz/rGO/ZnO NRs/P3HT/PEDOT:PSS/Au, which gave a PCE of around 0.31%. Graphene transparent electrodes can also be incorporated into Schottky junction solar cells. In 2010, Li et al. first reported the fabrication of such type of photovoltaic device by covering CVD-grown graphene on an ntype silicon (n-Si) substrate and showed a PCE of 1.5%.1131 After that, great efforts have been made to increase PCEs of graphene/Si Schottky junction solar cells. Currently, a record PCE of up to 15.6% was achieved by introducing a reflective TiO2 layer on the HNO3 doped graphene.
1133 When CVDgrown graphene was transferred onto the GaAs surface, the fabricated Schottky junction solar cell exhibited a PCE as high as 18.5%.1134
As discussed above, graphene transparent electrodes have been successfully applied in various types of solar cell devices and demonstrated impressive photovoltaic performances. Besides transparent electrodes, graphene can also be used as catalytic electrodes in DSSCs or charge transport layers in OPVs.1135,1136 To date, many related works have been published, contributing to the great development of graphene and graphene-based composites for solar cell applications.198
6.5.2. 2D TMD-Based Solar Cell Devices. Although multifunctional applications of graphene in photovoltaic devices have been achieved, the use of graphene as the absorber layer is a real struggle because of its low absorption coefficient and
metallic behavior due to the absence of a band gap. As compared to graphene, the abundance of and versatile electrical properties of ultrathin 2D TMDs make them attractive for a variety of applications in solar cell devices.128 TMDs can display metallic, semimetallic, semiconducting, and superconducting behaviors depending on the polytype and the band structure, which render them promising applications as interlayers or active layers in photovoltaic devices.1137 In earlier reports, the implementation of bulk TMDs for solar energy conversion is dependent on the fabrication of high-quality single crystals mainly by the chemical vapor transport method. Photoelectrochemical cells that adopted MoSe2 or WSe2 single crystal as the photoactive layer achieved conversion efficiencies between 10% and 20%.1138,1139 Great efforts have been also devoted to solid-state solar cells. Device combinations including Schottky barrier, metal−insulator−semiconductor, and p−n junction have been studied and exhibited decent conversion efficiencies.1140 Solid-state solar cells based on p-type WSe2/Al Schottky barrier junction and p-type WSe2/n-type ZnO heterojunction showed conversion efficiencies of 5.3% and 6.1%, respectively.1141,1142 The interest in ultrathin 2D TMDs warms up due to the simulation of research on graphene. As a consequence, the utilization of 2D TMDs for solar cell devices becomes hotspots in view of the successful graphene applications for solar energy conversion. Exfoliated TMDs can derive novel characteristics as a supplement to their intrinsic properties.
